item.title: Princess Eugenie treats fans to a rare glimpse inside Buckingham Palace as she shares a snap of Prince Andrew posing in a corridor lined with historic paintings, busts and opulent urns
item.description: The royal, 28, shared the snap on Instagram to celebrate her father's first Trooping The Colour as Colonel in Chief of the Grenadier Guards, an honour bestowed on him by the Queen in March.
item.content:encoded:
Proud Princess Eugenie has given royal fans a rare glimpse inside Buckingham Palace after sharing a candid snap of her father Prince Andrew on Instagram. 

The royal, 28, shared the snap to celebrate her father's first Trooping The Colour as Colonel in Chief of the Grenadier Guards, an honour bestowed on him by the Queen in March. 

'A wonderful and proud day celebrating Her Majesty’s birthday and @hrhthedukeofyork for his first Trooping the Colour as Colonel in Chief of the Grenadier Guards,' she wrote. 

Saturday's Trooping The Colour saw him ride out on the mall for the first time in full regalia and bearskins, alongside the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge and Princess Anne. 

Smiling Andrew, 58, looked smart in his regimental uniform as he posed in a corridor adorned with busts, paintings and huge free-standing urns.

An eagle eyed royal fan commented that the painting seen over his shoulder was of the wedding of Princess Maud of Wales, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria, who commissioned Laurits Regner Tuxen. 

The snap delighted royal fans with many commenting on how handsome the Duke of York looked in his uniform, while others were pleased to see him looking so happy in the photo. 

Saturday's Trooping The Colour saw him ride out on the mall for the first time in full regalia and bearskins, alongside the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Cambridge and Princess Anne.

Most members of the royal family do no have their personal Instagram accounts open to the public, but Eugenie is an exception. 

And since opening her account several months ago, she's delighted fans with her sense of humour and candid snaps. 

Recently she shared previously unseen photos of herself holding court at a Buckingham Palace reception, joking in the caption: 'In my next life looks like I could be a comedian.'

Earlier this month she she shared an unseen family snap with her sister Beatrice and parents the Duke and Duchess of York. 

'90s flashback with Bea and parents to when my father commanded HMS Cottesmore,' she said.
item.dc:abstract: Princess Eugenie, 28, (top right) shared the snap on Instagram to celebrate her father's first Trooping The Colour as Colonel in Chief of the Grenadier Guards. Smiling Andrew, who rode on The Mall for the first time (bottom right) posed in a corridor adorned with busts, huge free-standing urns and a portrait of Queen Victoria's granddaughter Princess Maud on her wedding day.
item.dc:creator: Siofra Brennan
item.mi:shortTitle: Princess Eugenie shares a rare glimpse inside Buckingham Palace

item.title: Nancy Dell'Olio, 56, claims women as young as EIGHTEEN should make more of an effort with their appearance (but adds the only way to be taken seriously is to 'dress like a man')
item.description: Nancy Dell'Olio, 56, appeared on ITV's Good Morning Britain where she said that all women should make more of an effort in their appearance and start taking care of themselves as soon as possible.
item.content:encoded:
Nancy Dell'Olio has blasted women who don't make enough of an effort, even those as young as 18.

The 56-year-old, who believes her glamorous appearance shaves off 20 years from her age, thinks some women are 'born old' and should start taking care of themselves sooner rather than later.

During an appearance on ITV's Good Morning Britain on Tuesday, the Italian-British lawyer discussed comments she made about older British women not looking sexy enough, claiming her quotes were taken out of context.

Instead Nancy, who was wearing dungarees, claimed the only way women could be taken seriously was to 'look like a man'.

Nancy, who displayed a youthful glow on the daytime show, blasted Brits for being obsessed with age: 'I never look at women by their age. It is not in my interest.

'The fact that this is another British obsession especially because you are a sexist country and a very masculine country. 

'It’s always about the age! Who cares about the age? The women are glamorous.'

The former Strictly Come Dancing star did however insist that all women should make more of an effort with their appearance.

'I do in general, from age 18 sometimes. Some people they are born old, some people they never get old.'

Nancy was joined on the couch by 70-year-old Tricia Cusden who started a beauty brand for older women.

She had taken issue with Nancy's intial comments about British women, with Piers commenting that her own youthful appearance was a 'walking, living testament to the success of your business'.

The reality star, who dated former England football boss Sven-Göran Eriksson and has lived in the UK for 18 years, added: 'It’s the fact that some women feel to be taken seriously they have to look like a man.

'I have lived in many countries, I was born in America and am an Italian, I lived in England for 18 years. 

'And talking about the average is exactly what it is and how they are... there are beautiful women.' 

Good Morning Britain airs weekdays on ITV from 6am
item.dc:abstract: Nancy Dell'Olio, 56, appeared on ITV's Good Morning Britain where she said that all women should make more of an effort in their appearance. The Italian-British lawyer, who believes that her glamorous appearance shaves off 20 years from her age, thinks that some women are 'born old' and should start taking care of themselves sooner rather than later.
item.dc:creator: Carol Driver
item.mi:shortTitle: Nancy Dell'Olio says older women do not make an effort to look sexy

item.title: Male escort, 48, who's slept with 1,000 women reveals how he went from software engineer to sex worker earning up to £1,200 per NIGHT - and insists his partner supports his career
item.description: Seani Love, 48, who is from Australia but lives in London, went from software engineer to sex worker after he began attending Tantra workshops and discovered his calling.
item.content:encoded:
Seani Love was working as a a software engineer when he attended his first sex workshop in an effort to 'spice things up' in the bedroom. 

Little did he know his new hobby would ultimately lead him to an entirely different career - as a male escort.

After being offered £130 for his first private session, Seani, now 48, who was born in Australia but is based in London, now charges as much as £1,200 to spend a night with a female client - offering anything from a 'kinky boyfriend' experience to role play. 

And while he admits he doesn't fit the 'stereotype of the buff, hairless, Chippendale-type male,' Seani says he's satisfied more than 1,000 clients by ensuring 'they have the best possible sexual experience when they're with me'. 

Scroll down to read Seani's story in his own words... 

'As I held the woman in my arms on the bed I asked her how she wanted to be touched. Minutes earlier she’d told me she’d never had an orgasm before so over the following 45 minutes I helped her climax for the first time ever. It was an amazing moment for the both of us – but it was also my job to make sure she left happy, as I was a male escort.

Eight years ago I was working in London as a software engineer and enjoyed it a lot. As someone who’s always been sexually adventurous in the bedroom and keen to try new things when I hit my thirties I began to go to workshops in my spare time, to learn about things such as Tantra and bondage – anything that would add a bit more spice in the bedroom.

But then eight years ago I ended up organising a sex workshop in London for my favourite sex book author. I wrote to him and asked if I could pay him to teach. After that I went to Prague to hold a workshop myself and a woman at the workshop offered to pay me £130 for a private session. I was surprised and delighted.

She admitted to me that she’d always felt quite shy when it came to sex and wanted me to give her an erotic massage – Something she’d never dared ask a partner for.

I felt very confident that I could give her exactly what she wanted. We did it in back room of the studio. When it was over, I felt so elated that I had managed to satisfy her and make her climax, I knew I could make a living out of it.

I did wonder how I would tell people what I was doing and I decided to keep it from my father. At first I kept working as a software engineer, while organising my own sex workshops in London and in my native Australia and offering my services as an escort.

These could be a ‘hands off experience' which is just chatting, or a ‘kinky boyfriend’ experience where I combine kink with intimacy such as spanking or role play or just sensual touch, sex and erotic play.

I advertised on Facebook and other websites charging from £90 an hour to £1,200 for a full day or overnight. I strictly never take my pants off in the first session so that my clients feel safe and are reassured it is all about their needs not mine. I just meet and greet them and give a massage.

I never confessed to any of my engineer colleagues about my secret side job, but as my reputation grew over the next four years, I was able to give up my office job in June 2015 and work full time in the sex industry.

By then I had a really strong client base of women in their 30s and 40s. Many had experienced a string of bad relationships and want to explore sex for themselves, while others were pretty high powered women who want to surrender to their sexuality and be more submissive. I even had one famous client who appeared on TV regularly!

Lots of my clients have also never climaxed before they’d been with me, which I felt was just so sad, as it’s such a natural and wonderful thing. But one of them ended up having really noisy orgasms once she discovered them, which was very funny. I meet clients at home and I remember once she practically screamed my house down while we were having sex.

When she left, my neighbours, who have no idea what I do, gave me some really funny looks.

In 2015 I met my current partner at a Tantric sex workshop. From the start I was very open about my work with her and thankfully she’s always been very positive and encouraging. I imagine it’s because she’s also interested in exploring sex and can see that I’m helping empower women and their sexuality. She knows I practice safe sex and always use a condom.

At the moment we live in different cities as she is from the Netherlands and we have a long distance love. So we can't always be together and at times she can feel insecure that I am having sex with other women but she understands about my job and is supportive.

Not everyone is so understanding, though. I am always open in conversation and while some men tell me it’s their dream job, others have accused me of lying, as I don't fit the stereotype of the buff, hairless, Chippendale type male. And I often get asked why a woman would pay for sex with me when they can just pick someone up at a bar.

I have slept with around 1,000 women since I began and the truth is that if a woman is paying then the whole time it is about them and their needs and what she wants to explore. Some women have no idea what they want, or how to ask for it and some have only had sex that lasted 10 minutes. That’s why I make it my job to make sure they have the best possible sexual experience when they’re with me.'
item.dc:abstract: Seani Love, 48, who is from Australia but lives in London, went from software engineer to sex worker after he began attending Tantra workshops and discovered his calling. He started advertising on Facebook and can now charge anything from £90 an hour to £1,200 for a full day or overnight session.

item.title: The OTHER Spencer! Heir to Blenheim Palace is a party-loving polo player who's pals with Harry and is giving cousin Kitty a run for her money with his jet-set lifestyle
item.description: George Blandford, who will one day inherit Blenheim Palace and an estimated £100m fortune from his father, is giving Kitty a run for her money by sharing a glimpse into his charmed life.
item.content:encoded:
Kitty Spencer may be one of the most famous young royals around.

But George Blandford has been giving his cousin a run for her money of late by posting photos of his jet-setting, party-loving lifestyle online.

The 25-year-old aristocrat and polo player, who will one day inherit Blenheim Palace and an estimated £100m fortune, is making quite a name for himself on social media by sharing an extraordinary glimpse into his charmed life.

The well-heeled aviation broker - whose full name is George John Godolphin Spencer-Churchill, Marquess of Blandford - is the son of James Spencer-Churchill, 12th Duke of Marlborough and his first wife Rebecca Mary Few Brown. 

He also works as a model and brand ambassador for polo company La Martina, and has played against Prince Harry on the polo field.

Scroll down for video 

George became Marquess of Blandford in 2014, following his grandfather's death and was named last year by Tatler as one of the '10 most eligible people in the land'. 

But singletons will be disappointed to learn the Harrow-educated UCL graduate is set to the knot this year with childhood sweetheart Camilla Thorp, an interior designer who he met when he was just 16.

As future marchioness, Camilla will one day preside over 187-room Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire with her husband.

George, who is a distant relative of Winston Churchill (the wartime PM was his great-great-uncle), Diana Princess of Wales, and the Vanderbilt dynasty, can often be seen entertaining friends behind the walls of his family's eighteenth-century pile. 

Recent gatherings at the 2,000-acre estate include a Christmas party, not to mention countless overseas jaunts for work and play. 

There have also been countless foreign trips to Miami, Las Vegas, Istanbul, Verbier, and a private chateau in northern France.

And in January, he walked the runway for Dolce & Gabbana at Milan Fashion Week. 

Among his inner circle are Ella May Sangster, granddaughter of the late horse-racing magnate Robert, and chocolate heiress Jemima Cadbury. 

The future Duke boasts a pilot's license and 'an adorable smile', according to Tatler, and is building a reputation for being a seriously impressive polo player having played alongside Prince Harry himself at Cirencester - and beating him.

In a recent interview he said: 'My family has always been into horses, so from hunting and riding, I sort of progressed to polo. 

'I started playing at school, and then when I left school I kept on playing some club polo, in Cirencester where I play today.' 

He is currently busy training for an upcoming Transatlantic row challenge for Starlight charity.

The Spencer-Churchill clan was born when Anne Churchill, daughter of the first Duke of Marlborough, married Charles Spencer, 3rd Earl of Sunderland.
item.dc:abstract: George Blandford, who will one day inherit Blenheim Palace (top right) and an estimated £100m fortune from his father the 12th Duke of Marlborough, is giving distant cousin Kitty (inset left) a run for her money by entertaining thousands of followers with a glimpse into his extraordinarily privileged life. The aviation broker - whose full name is George John Godolphin Spencer-Churchill, Marquess of Blandford - also works as a model and brand ambassador for polo company La Martina and has even played against Prince Harry (inset right).
item.dc:creator: Unity Blott
item.mi:shortTitle: Heir to Blenheim Palace is a party-loving polo player

item.title: 'This is the first mask that has made a visible difference': The anti-ageing product Lara Bingle, 30, swears by for a youthful, glowing complexion
item.description: Lara Bingle knows a thing or two about skincare. The Australian beauty recently shared her favourite anti-ageing product on Instagram. But would you spend this much money to get flawless skin like Lara?
item.content:encoded:
Lara Worthington (nee Bingle) is known for her frank and honest beauty advice, as well as her impossibly clear skin.

So when the Australian model and beauty brand owner speaks about the benefits of a product, you can bet FEMAIL sits up an listens.

Renowned for her flawless visage, fans of Lara, 30, hang on her every recommendation when it comes to achieving the perfect complexion.

The latest addition to her stack of cult favourites is the Intense Facial Mask from high end skin care brand Verso.

Announcing that she 'highly recommends' the beauty item on her much-watched Instagram stories, Ms Bingle said that this sheet mask was the first she has tried that made a 'visible difference' to her (already) glowing complexion.

Model-turned-entrepreneur Lara has her own successful skincare range, The Base, so you can be sure she knows a thing or two about matters of the face. 

The deeply hydrating, anti-ageing mask is made with grapefruit extract and Retinol 8 which stimulates natural collagen production to give the appearance of plumper, younger and softer skin.

Described by the brand as a 'moisturising and rejuvenating' hydrogel sheet, the mask is infused with vitamin A for an extra treat to your skin.

The mask is designed for use once or twice weekly. 

Launched in 2013, Stockholm-based Verso aims to target the skin's daily needs by utilising scientific formulae in its products.

In keeping with its science-centric brand, Verso's head office is located in the same building as the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.

Verso's Intense Facial Mask is available now from Mecca online for $117.
item.dc:abstract: Lara Bingle (pictured on the official Instagram for her skincare range The Base, left, and on her personal account, right) is known for her frank and honest beauty recommendations. So when the Australian model and beauty brand owner speaks about the benefits of a product, you can bet FEMAIL sits up an listens. Renowned for her flawless visage, fans of Lara, 30, hang on her every recommendation when it comes to achieving the perfect complexion. The latest addition to her stack of cult favourites is the Intense Facial Mask from high end skin care brand Verso (inset, being tested by Lara).
item.dc:creator: Laura House
item.mi:shortTitle: The groundbreaking anti-ageing face mask Lara Bingle swears by

item.title: Mother who wants to take her two children on holiday during term time while they're studying for their GCSEs is told to 'just do it' - but would YOU?
item.description: British Mumsnet user toomuchpopcorn wants to take her two children out of school so they can visit San Francisco, but is unsure if they should be missing the last week of the school term.
item.content:encoded:
Taking your children out of school so they can go on holiday is always a controversial decision for a parent to make and one that rarely goes down well with the school.

Between weighing up holiday costs with a potential fine and, most importantly, whether missing school will negatively affect your children many will choose to adhere to the official school holidays.

However, Mumsnet user toomuchpopcorn took to the site to admit she was considering taking her children out of school so they can visit friends in San Francisco.

In a post on the parenting site the mother explained that her children are in Year 10 and 'work hard' but would need to miss at least the last few days of term to make the trip abroad worthwhile.

She says that they have missed very little school and she isn't sure if lessons are even scheduled for the last week of term. 

She wrote: 'Kids have been offered the opportunity to visit friends in San Francisco where they will learn how to surf, climb hills, camp, etc.

'But to co-ordinate with US school holidays and to make flying across the world worthwhile they would probably need to take the last few days off school otherwise they'd only have one week.

'They are in Year 10 and they have missed very little school, maybe one of them has missed half a day, they work hard and do pretty well. 

'During this last week I'm not even sure the school schedule lessons.' 

She received a lot of support from fellow Mumsnet users who encouraged her to take the children out of school.

One user said: 'As a teacher, I say go for it. How exciting for them!'

Another commented: 'Do it. They learn nothing in the last few days of term - it's taking stuff off walls and watching DVDs. Sounds amazing!'

One added: 'Just do it (retired teacher here..) - if my mum insisted that I spent the last few days of the year sitting about doing nothing at school, when I could have been in San Francisco, there would have been words.'

However, some were less receptive to the woman's message while others warned her that the last week of school is still important.

One user said: 'Loving the assumption that all secondary schools do nothing during the last week of term

'My daughter's school run their academic year from the end of June to the end of June. 

'The new academic year starts at the beginning of July, so a year 10 student would be starting year 11 work then. Missing an entire week the last week of term would mean missing quite a lot of content. 

'They don't do any work on the last day though.'

Another warned: 'We couldn't have done it as Year 10 work experience is always the last week of the Summer term as a PP said.

'I would check that they wouldn't miss any Year 11 stuff.'

While a teacher added: 'Just to sound a word of warning though, I wouldn't be putting together any missed work for them. 

'I'd suggest they asked their friends for notes or missed homework, but wouldn't do extra work to compensate for them deciding to go on holiday myself.'
item.dc:abstract: British Mumsnet user toomuchpopcorn wants to take her two children out of school so they can visit San Francisco, but is unsure if they should be missing the last week of the school term. Her children are in Year 10 and she says that they have barely missed a day of school between them. She also believes that their school doesn't have any lessons planned for the last day of term.
item.dc:creator: Carol Driver
item.mi:shortTitle: Taking kids out of school for last few days of summer term

item.title: Heidi Klum unveils a festival range for Lidl starting from £2.49 and including some VERY convincing designer lookalikes - so can YOU tell which is which?
item.description: Heidi Klum has once again teamed up with the budget UK supermarket Lidl, this time on a summer range that contains everything you need for your festival wardrobe - including designer lookalikes.
item.content:encoded:
With festival season in full swing, many party-goers will be looking to stock up on the latest boho trends.

Now providing budget versions of must-have looks is supermodel Heidi Klum, who has teamed up with the cut-price supermarket Lidl to release a range of festival-inspired pieces at purse-friendly prices. 

Items start from just £2.49, and with supermodel Heidi's touch, the range, which launches on the 17th June, has the feel of a far more expensive line. 

Heidi's designers include a pair of chic black wedges for £14.99 that look just like a £70 pair from Tommy Hilfiger.  

An £11.99 kimono-inspired kaftan bears a distinct resemblance to a Matthew Williamson number that costs a staggering £338.   

So can you tell Heidi's Lidl pieces from their designer dupes?
item.dc:abstract: German supermodel Heidi Klum has once again teamed up with the budget UK supermarket Lidl, this time on a summer range that contains everything you need for your festival wardrobe. The range starts from just £2.49, and includes pieces that bear a striking resemblance to much more expensive (left to right) kimonos, denim dresses, kaftans and wedges.

item.title: Exasperated mother who considered SHAVING off her daughter's hair after seven failed head lice treatments finally discovers a £5.49 overnight cure
item.description: Joanne, 30, from Hampshire tried seven different remedies on six-year-old Poppy's hair, including three different lotions that claim to eradicate head lice over the course of three weeks.
item.content:encoded:
A mother who couldn't get rid of her daughter's constant head lice infestation has revealed how she even considered shaving off her little girls long locks to beat the problem. 

Joanne Hedges, 30, from Hampshire tried seven different remedies on six-year-old Poppy's hair, including three different lotions that claim to eradicate head lice over the course of three weeks. 

And Poppy was left feeling frustrated and unhappy after dealing with constant itching, as well as sitting for hours every single night having her thick hair brushed through with the nit comb. 

'After three weeks, I was at my wits end and I was thinking, 'I'm going to have to shave off all her lovely hair if this carries on',' mother-of-three Joanne recalled. 'I felt helpless.'

It was only when she discovered a £5.49 overnight solution, Hedrin Treat & Go that she managed to combat the problem. 

'I put the Hedrin lotion on before bed time, left it overnight and then washed it out in the morning,' she explained. 'Then we repeated the treatment after seven days and my god, it actually worked. The lice were gone.'

'I couldn't believe it. The whole family was relieved. Poppy was so sick of the nit comb and I was bored of sitting on the sofa trawling through her hair inch by inch every night – it took hours – and hurt Poppy.

'Hedrin even made her hair feel really soft after we'd used it. It brushed through well and didn't hurt her head either.'

Joanne first discovered lice in Poppy's hair just before she finished school for the summer last year. 

'I thought to myself this is an absolute nightmare, it's the last thing I want to deal with over the summer holidays,' she explained. 

'I was determined to get rid of the lice as soon as possible so we could be head lice free for the start of the holidays. I went straight down the shops to find a solution.'

Despite being aware that head lice is a common issue, Joanne couldn't help feeling 'mortified'.  

'When I saw the lice crawling around in Poppy's hair I felt panicked,' she explained. 

'I bought a product which claimed to work in five minutes. It sounded great but when I checked Poppy's hair afterwards the lice were still crawling around so it hadn't worked. 

'The next product I tried was an organic treatment which also didn't kill the lice. 

'Poppy was getting sick and tired of me trawling through her hair, using different treatments and combing every little section. 

'Poppy has Afro-European hair which means there's lots of it and it's not easy to comb through on the best of days, let alone various times a week using a fine toothed nit comb.'

Joanne then tried a different approach, and bought a shampoo that she thought would be gentler on Poppy's hair and less hassle, but the lice were still there afterwards. 

'Then we tried three, yes three, different types of head lice lotion before I finally found a solution,' she said. 

Joanne paid a visit to Boots to speak to the pharmacist about the issue and was recommended Hedrin Treat & Go. 

The formula contains a diol called 1,2 octanediol which strips away the waxy cuticle on the louse, causing them to dehydrate. 

This prevents head lice from developing a resistance to treatment, which is a common problem with traditional pesticides.

'It really appealed to me that it was an overnight treatment.'

After two treatments seven days apart, the lice were finally gone and haven't returned.  

''We now check the whole family for lice on a weekly basis and so far we've been lucky - they haven't returned,' she added.

What causes head lice? 

Around one in 10 primary school children in the UK has head lice - tiny insects which live and lay their eggs in hair. Their empty egg cases which stick to hair are known as 'nits'.

Lice quickly multiply and can cause itching and inflammation of the scalp. In severe cases, infections can be caused when children scratch their head with dirty fingernails or if faecal matter from the lice gets into a scratch.

Parasitologist Ian Burgess, director of the Medical Entomology Centre in Cambridge last year warned that increasing number of parents are failing to treat head lice in their children because they fear using chemicals or simply 'can't be bothered'.

'Head lice can be tough to eradicate and there's lots of incorrect information online so it's difficult for parents to know what to do,' he said. 

'I often hear about bizarre things people think up to use such as mayonnaise, vinegar, peroxide and even household bleach being suggested online. 

'This gives worried parents misplaced confidence in ineffective methods. And if treatment is not effective then, head lice are allowed to spread further and more quickly. 

'I've heard of mums dyeing their child's hair in an attempt to kill the lice. This seemed to be effective because they couldn't find lice, but in fact the lice had just been dyed along with the hair. 

'I can't stress enough the importance of parents asking for a clinically proven solution when they visit their local pharmacy. This will ensure that the lice are eradicated.'
item.dc:abstract: Joanne, 30, from Hampshire tried seven different remedies on six-year-old Poppy's hair, including three different lotions that claim to eradicate head lice over the course of three weeks, but nothing worked. The constant coming and treatment was painful for Poppy and Joanne even feared she'd have to shave her head, before she was recommended £5.49 Hedrin Treat & Go, which eradicated the lice for good.
item.dc:creator: Siofra Brennan
item.mi:shortTitle: Mother considered shaving daughter's head to beat lice

item.title: 'He plagiarised an essay ABOUT plagiarism': Teachers reveal the most brainless things their students have ever done in a hilarious online thread
item.description: Fed up teachers from around the world have been revealing the silliest things their students have ever said to them online - including one who thought Leo DiCaprio was dead due to his role in Titanic.
item.content:encoded:
'There's no such thing as a stupid question', according to the old saying, however these students really put the adage to the test. 

An hilarious new thread compiled by BoredPanda has seen teachers share the silliest things their students have ever said to them.

In the anonymous thread, professors detail tales of students who brazenly plagiarised their work, and openly asked questions which would be expected only from much younger children.

Astonished teachers told how students frequently confused fact with fiction, with one recalling a pupil convinced Leonardo DiCaprio was dead because of his role in the disaster movie Titanic.  

The teacher wrote: 'High School Teacher. Many years ago, I was showing my students clips from Romeo and Juliet. Student stared at the screen in total bewilderment for a few minutes.

'Then she said, serious as a cancer diagnosis, "How can he be in this movie? He died in Titanic."'

Many others admitted that they had their patience tested by hapless students.

One wrote: 'I didn't believe any student was dumb- he/she may have only needed the right motivation. 

'Until I met RJ. RJ was dumb. RJ didn't realise that the chicken we eat is the same as the animal. RJ was 21 at the time.' 

Others were baffled by the pure cheek of some of their students.

One said: 'A friend was substitute teaching a high school math class and was to proctor a test for the students. 

'At one point during the test a student got up to ask if he knew what 8 x 7 was, but before he could respond another student said 'sit down... he doesn't know the answer to that... he's a substitute teacher not a maths teacher.'

Another wrote: 'I once gave a university student a C on a philosophy paper. She looked at me and said, "Do you know who my father is?" To this day, I don't know who he was, but her grade did not change.'

Another teacher said: 'One student asking the difference between psychopath and psychologist in criminology class.'
item.dc:abstract: Fed up teachers from around the world have been revealing the silliest things their students have ever said to them online - including one who thought Leo DiCaprio was dead due to his role in Titanic. Another told of a former student who didn't realise that the chicken we eat and chicken the animal are one and the same.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Mcdermott
item.mi:shortTitle: Lecturers reveal why they've questioned their students intelligence

item.title: And you thought YOUR parents were bad! Hilarious snaps reveal the VERY creative ways mums and dads have trolled their children
item.description: A hilarious new online gallery compiled by Bored Panda has revealed the very creative ways parents have trolled their unsuspecting children.
item.content:encoded:
It is well known that parents are experts when it comes to embarrassing their youngsters, however, these mums and dads really take the biscuit.

A hilarious new online gallery compiled by Bored Panda has revealed the very creative ways parents have trolled their unsuspecting children.

In these cases it seems that nothing is too much effort with one family assembling in full fancy dress to meet their daughter at the airport.

Elsewhere adults are more than happy to remind their children who pays for the wifi, changing the password until they have completed their chores.

And then there are those who openly mock their offspring including one mum and dad who meticulously recreate their daughter's selfies.

Whether they make you laugh or cringe, these photos are sure to serve as a reminder that mother (and father) knows best!

item.title: Can you spot what's unusual about this new mince? Woolworths comes under fire after the placement of their latest product angers shoppers
item.description: At first glance, this product looks like any other mince. But eagle-eyed shoppers have noticed something unusual about the product, found in the cold meat section of Australian supermarket Woolworths.
item.content:encoded:
At first glance, this product looks like any other mince meat.

But eagle-eyed shoppers have noticed something different about the product, which was found in the cold meat section of Australian supermarket giant Woolworths.

So can you spot what's unusual about the mince?

Upon closer inspection the mince, retailed at $8, is 100 per cent plant-based.

An alternative to mince meat, vegan Australian company Funky Fields has launched its revolutionary new product, made entirely from plants.

And while the latest meat-free product to hit shelves has delighted vegans everywhere, some were not impressed with the placement of the mince.

'This is fantastic! Plant-based mince. Thank you! But why put it in the meat section?' a shopper said on the supermarket giant's Facebook page.

'As is the case with many vegans, I'm repulsed that you ever have a meat section and give it a very wide berth, as the smell of blood is disgusting to me.

'Vegans wouldn't think to look there, nor would they be keen to go there. Please consider stocking it in a vegan section of your supermarket. Thank you.'

Another customer said: 'Fantastic that you have 100 per cent plant-based mince. Can you please move it away from the real meat? 

'I don't go in that aisle and won't buy it if it's near dead animals. A better option would be to put it with the rest of your meat free options. Thanks.'

One shopper chimed in, saying the placement of the product could be a good thing.

'I think having it in the meat section might convince the occasional omnivore to choose the vegan option,' she said.

A Woolworths spokesperson told Daily Mail Australia: 'We know some customers are looking to eat less traditional protein in their diets, either by introducing smaller portions, balancing meat and vegetable protein, or looking for 100 per cent meat replacement options. 

'In response we are pleased to range the Funky Fields plant-based mince alternative, Minced, in our meat section to meet this demand.'

Catering for people who lead a vegan diet, the Australian-first plant-based 'Minced' has the same structure of meat and even the same protein content.

'It has the same structure, same use and cooking method, and tastes like meat,' the company said.
item.dc:abstract: At first glance, this product looks like any other mince meat. But eagle-eyed shoppers have noticed something different about the product, which was found in the cold meat section of Australian supermarket giant Woolworths. So can you spot what's unusual about the mince?
item.dc:creator: Cindy Tran
item.mi:shortTitle: Can you spot what's unusual about this new mince?

item.title: Kate’s favourite off-duty brand: How the Duchess of Cambridge turns to Zara pieces costing as little as £39.99 for her casual wardrobe - and experts say it showcases her 'true style'
item.description: The Duchess of Cambridge, 36, was spotted wearing a £39.99 dress from Zara while at a charity polo match in Gloucestershire on Sunday, showcasing her more relaxed style.
item.content:encoded:
She's known for her love of high-end designers such as Alexander McQueen - but the Duchess of Cambridge's favourite off-duty brand is a much more affordable choice: the High Street retailer Zara.

Kate, 36, was spotted wearing a £39.99 striped dress from the retailer while at a charity polo match in Gloucestershire on Sunday, showcasing her more relaxed style when not at official engagements.

The mother-of-three had opted for another summer dress by Zara, also priced at £39.99, while at the Houghton Horse Trials with Prince George, four, and Princess Charlotte, three, at the end of last month.

The Duchess is clearly a big fan of the High Street brand, wearing Zara on a number of occasions in the past - particularly when off-duty.

Looking to keep a low-profile, Kate wore a £89.99 checked coat from Zara when at London's King's Cross station back in December.

She also opted for a £95.99 Zara cape when she made a surprise appearance at The Nutcracker at the Royal Opera House, after joining other members of the royal family for the Queen's annual Christmas lunch last year. 

Meanwhile, eagle-eyed royal watchers spotted that the Duchess picked a £39.99 Zara floral dress to wear to sister Pippa Middleton's wedding last May, seemingly not want to take the spotlight away from her younger sibling.  

Celebrity stylist Rochelle White said Kate's love of Zara is a reflection of the Duchess's 'true style'.

She told FEMAIL: 'I think Kate wearing Zara is reflection of who she is and the type of fashion she would choose if not a royal. 

'Kate is a normal girl at heart who hasn’t lost her sense of style or who she is because she is a princess. 

'I feel that Zara is a brand that helps her keep a sense of self and shows of her own fashion choices when not in royal mode.' 

She added: 'It makes sense why she chooses Zara as her go-to brand for her off-duty look, as it is a High Street brand that offers great style, functionality and comfort that appeals to most women.

'Many women look up to Kate as a fashion icon, whether Kate is aware of this or not, I feel she is conscious of her choices and tries to pick brands that appeals to her audience.'

The Duchess doesn't just reserve Zara for her off-duty looks though, opting for a £49.99 red coat by the retailer for the Queen's birthday celebrations in 2016.

She also wore a pair of £29.99 khaki trousers from the brand during her tour of India during the same year.

Kate also showed off a number of Zara pieces on first joining the royal family, most memorably wearing a £49.99 blue dress from the brand on her first public appearance after tying the knot with Prince William in 2011.
item.dc:abstract: The Duchess of Cambridge, 36, was spotted wearing a £39.99 dress from Zara while at a charity polo match in Gloucestershire on Sunday (far left), showcasing her more relaxed style. The mother-of-three had opted for another summer dress by Zara (top left), also priced at £39.99, while at the Houghton Horse Trials last month. Kate was also spotted wearing a £89.99 checked coat from Zara when at London's King's Cross station back in December (centre), as well as a £95.99 Zara cape while making a surprise appearance at The Nutcracker at the Royal Opera House in the same month (far right). Kate wore a £39.99 floral dress by Zara (top right) for sister Pippa's wedding reception last May.
item.dc:creator: Carol Driver
item.mi:shortTitle: How the Duchess of Cambridge turns to Zara when off-duty

item.title: 'I did a happy dance around the kitchen... I sold out': Australian mum, 32, sees her bespoke candle business skyrocket after Hollywood star Katherine Heigl posts gushing review
item.description: A Sydney-based mum has been left run off her feet trying to fill orders for her candle range. She said after they featured on a blog post by American actress Katherine Heigl, they sold out.
item.content:encoded:
A mum-of-one and bespoke candle maker has just had her first taste of international success - thanks to a Hollywood actress who told the world how much she loves her work.

Jacqueline Cohen, 32, based on Sydney's North Shore, runs small bespoke soy business Écru Candles - a labour of love she's pursued since 2016.

While she's been steadily selling her candles via her website, she said all that changed quickly after she received an email from a producer at These Heavenly Days - an American blog curated by former Grey's Anatomy star Katherine Heigl.

She said within 24 hours of the candles being featured on the blog, she had sold out.

'I didn't know what to do with myself apart from a happy dance around the kitchen,' the mother-of-one said. 

Ms Cohen's candles were featured as a part of a blog post entitled 'Artisan Picks: May 2018' where the actress shared a list of her must-have luxury items.

'Not only are these candles in beautiful ceramic containers, but the beautiful ceramic containers are re-usable!' Katherine wrote.

She also went on to say the variety of scents and 'their simple modern look' made them 'gift closet worthy' - adding, 'Though, honestly, I might just gift a bunch for myself.' 

As well as the post, the actress also shared a photo of the handmade ceramic candles to her 2.4million Instagram followers with a caption that read:

'I just love browsing for artisan treasures - beautiful items made with skill and craft that make wonderful gifts or treats for yourself!

'Couldn't resist sharing a few of my latest delectable finds with you in today's blog post. Enjoy!'

The post received over 28,000 likes and with 24 hours, the Sydney-based entrepreneur said the candles had sold out.

'I had sold out of my "Up in the Clouds" candles and had to quickly remake some more.

'The feedback and new orders I've had since then are just incredible.'

The busy mum, who is also expecting her second child, said she is so grateful for the support and even joked she was considering naming her unborn daughter after the Hollywood star.

'I just can't thank Katherine enough for support a small one-woman-band.'
item.dc:abstract: A Sydney-based mum, Jacqueline Cohen, 32, (top right) has been left run off her feet trying to fill orders for her candle range (bottom right). She said after they featured on a blog post by American actress Katherine Heigl (left), they sold out and she is doing all she can to keep up with demand: 'The feedback and new orders I've had since then are just incredible.'
item.dc:creator: Laura House
item.mi:shortTitle: Mum sees her candle business take off after Hollywood star's blog post

item.title: Do you know the real reason 'Baby on Board' signs exist? Shocked drivers urged to spread the word after learning the sticker's 'true purpose'
item.description: They're a common sight on Australian roads, but few know the significance of a 'Baby on Board' sign when they place it inside their car window.
item.content:encoded:
They're a common sight on Australian roads, but few know the real meaning of the 'Baby on Board' sign placed by many parents on their car windows. 

Taking to Facebook recently, a mother shared a snap of a typical 'Baby on Board' sign after hearing people label them as 'annoying'. 

'In case you don't know the true purpose of these signs... no you're not supposed to 'drive slower' around these people, no you're not supposed to worship them or tread lightly around them because they have a baby,' she wrote alongside the photo. 

'Baby on Board signs alert first responders that there is a person in the vehicle that is incapable of unbuckling themselves in the event of an accident. Do the EMTs need to look for a body that was possibly expelled from the vehicle?' 

However, police have previously confirmed the signs are not for that purpose.

'The sign is not for emergency services, but more of a notice to other drivers. Anyone using these signs must ensure they are not obstructing the driver's view,' a spokesperson for NSW Police told the NRMA. 

While those in the emergency services have confirmed that these signs do help alert first responders to the presence of a child in a car accident, the signs were also designed to alert other drivers to the 'precious cargo' inside.

In fact, it was an impatient driver that inspired the creation of these signs in the first place.

According to the NRMA Australia, 'the idea was born from the personal experience and desire of one man, Michael Lerner, a former real estate investor from Massachusetts, USA with the vision to keep children safe during car trips'.

In 1984 Mr Lerner was driving his 18-month-old nephew home and experienced 'busy traffic' and motorists 'tailgating and cutting him off throughout the trip'.

'For the first time, I felt like a parent feels when they have a kid in the car,' he said. 

The first sign was produced in 1984 within the first month, 10,000 were sold. 

Eight months on, 500,000 signs were selling each month.
item.dc:abstract: They're a common sight on Australian roads, but few know the significance of a 'Baby on Board' sign when they place it inside their car window. Taking to Facebook recently, a mother shared a snap of a typical 'Baby on Board' sign after hearing people label them as 'annoying'. 'In case you don't know the true purpose of these signs... no you're not supposed to "drive slower" around these people, no you're not supposed to worship them or tread lightly around them because they have a baby,' she wrote.
item.dc:creator: Laura House
item.mi:shortTitle: Do you know the real reason 'Baby on Board' signs exist?

item.title: Would you live in a flat pack home? From a mirrored box to a place inspired by a DUMPSTER - a look at prefab properties you can build in a few hours for as little as $5250
item.description: Flat pack homes are all the rage right now, as millennials and would-be homeowners muscle their way onto the property market. Here, FEMAIL takes a look at the trend for prefabricated houses.
item.content:encoded:
Looking to get on the property market? It seems that all you might need is a tiny budget, a few tools and a bit of patience.

Flat pack homes are all the rage right now, as millennials and would-be homeowners muscle their way onto the property market via affordable miniature homes that cost little and can be built in mere hours.

Here, FEMAIL takes a look at the trend for prefabricated houses that can be built in 24 hours or less. 

Because who said tiny doesn't equal beautiful?

The first company you could take a look at, should you want to get in on the flat pack home trend, is MADI Home.

Based in Italy, the innovative company can deliver their homes to virtually anywhere in the world - and they 'can be built without the need for it to be constructed on concrete foundations'.

The best part about these properties is that the entire assembly process requires just six hours time from three people.

The foldable home also cost just $45,000 and comes in a variety of sizes.

Invest in the property, and decide on your perfect location. Whether it's off-grid or somewhere less remote, the homes will work, as MADI highlight that their properties can be built with solar panels, LED lighting and grey water systems.

Next on the tiny housing market are properties are the options from KODA by KODASEMA.

Their minimalist home costs around $170,000 and can be put together in under seven hours.

On their website, Koda write: 'A single lorry to carry it in one piece and a crane to nest it in, KODA will move with you where ever your ideas, career and life take you'.

And while you might not be able to believe it, the tiny property does include its own bathroom, mezzanine floor for sleeping and tiny terraced area at the back.

'One day for installation – pack the toothbrush and move in,' their website conclude.

Elsewhere, you can try your hand at purchasing a micro home by Kasita.

Inspired by the founder Jeff Wilson's time in a 33 square foot dumpster - which he did to test the limits of habitable space - Jeff later founded and developed a new category of housing - a 'beautiful, small footprint home designed as a solution for the growing housing crisis'. 

These days, the so-called 'Kasita' looks nothing like a dumpster. Instead, it boasts hardwood flooring, a frameless glass shower, 374 square feet and light that floods through the building.

Another option is a home that doesn't even require you to build it.

Ten Fold's self-building property unfolds in just ten minutes and builds itself. You can also get all sorts of different houses, whether you're into a tree house-style structure or a beach house.

Finally, the ICON home - which is able to be built in under 24 hours and occupies between 600 and 800 square feet - is an option.

Costing just $5,250, it's cute and perfect for those looking for a life less simple. 

Alternatively, the OOD House boasts a stylish mirrored exterior which is perfect for those looking for an escape from the real world.
item.dc:abstract: Looking to get on the property market? It seems that all you might need is a tiny budget, a few tools and a bit of patience. Flat pack homes are all the rage right now, as millennials and would-be homeowners muscle their way onto the property market via affordable miniature homes that cost little and can be built in mere hours (pictured). Here, FEMAIL takes a look at the trend for prefabricated houses that can be built in 24 hours or less. Because who said tiny doesn't equal beautiful?

item.title: 'People's bodies naturally deviate': Small-of-stature actress Kiruna Stamell, 37, who stands at just over a metre, is smashing stereotypes one dramatic role at a time
item.description: Australian actress Kiruna Stamell may be short of stature, but she's a powerhouse on the stage and screen. She says her career, one that's built on grit and determination, has no place for stereotypes.
item.content:encoded:
Australian Kiruna Stamell may be small of stature, but she's a powerhouse on the stage and screen.

The 37-year-old was born with a rare form of dwarfism which means she stands at just over a metre tall.

The actress, one with an impressive list of roles under her belt, has stared in award winning movies including Moulin Rouge and the Ricky Gervais' comedy Life's Too Short.  

Not to mention three stage productions at London's prestigious National Theatre.

She says her career, one that's built on grit and determination, has no place for stereotypes - of any kind. 

Scroll down for video 

'It's interesting that people think I challenge expectations, from my point of view I am just being truthful,' she said during a recent interview on the Today Show.

The Sydney-born Kiruna said she has never actively campaigned to be recognised in a particular way, more she is trying to be 'honest' in portraying the human experience.

'I am playing the "human being" in different circumstances,' she said.

'Rather than falling back into those old stereotypes of what other people like me should be playing, or doing or talking about.'

She said before she accepts any roles, she first thinks about whether or not it would be something little Kiruna would find helpful to see.

Her attitude towards an industry that often typecasts people based on how they look means she is recognised first and foremost for her ability - skills she has spent years honing.

The classically trained contemporary dancer has been performing since she was three - even if as a toddler this was to her own invented choreography.

She said growing up, her parents instilled a sense she could do anything she wanted but were realistic about the fact people would judge her on her size.

Kiruna credits her dad for helping her develop a more resilient attitude, one that allowed her not to fall prey to an idea she was inadequate in any way.

'He said "People are going to judge you based on how you look, so don't do the work for them. They are going to judge you to be yourself",' she recalled. 

And although she grew up with a feeling nothing was wrong with her, she said media portrayals at the time were so damaging.

She said remembers thinking she was 'genuinely unlovable, that nobody would want to be with me, that I was weird.'

This flew in the face of a deeper belief about herself that she was normal which she said begged the question: Why aren't I seeing women like me represented in a truthful way?

Changing stereotypes, one brilliant role at a time, has been something that has touched the lives of others, especially those who feel their bodies don't fit the norm.

The actress shared how people had made the effort to get in touch with her to thank her and to say how nice it was to see her being human and real.

Although Kiruna is out to change perceptions she also advocates for those who have disabilities.

She said part of this is to identify as disabled because she believes by having some visibility she can raise awareness about decisions being made to fund accessibility or modify buildings for those who need better access.

'People's bodies naturally deviate (from the norm) and I think it's healthy to accommodate for that because it also bolsters those whose bodies are average to know their bodies are allowed to break down, be vulnerable and deviate.

'I just see it as all part of a healthy society and a truthful one.'

While the actress has had to overcome her share of struggles, she hasn't had to do this alone. 

Her husband Gareth Berliner, who she met at a comedy show, has been by her side for the past eight years and describes her as 'a really clever, beautiful woman who's a very talented actress, and that's bottom line.'

Despite his 'clucky' nature though, motherhood isn't something the actress has ever given serious thought.

She believes her 'quest' in life is important but that being a mum may not be a part of that.
item.dc:abstract: Australian actress Kiruna Stamell (left and right) may be short of stature, but she's a powerhouse on the stage and screen.The 37-year-old was born with a rare form of dwarfism which means she stands at just over a metre tall. She's an actor with an impressive list of roles under her belt including performances in Moulin Rouge (inset), long-running British soap the East Enders as well as the Ricky Gervais comedy Life's Too Short and the Geoffrey Rush movie The Best Offer. She says her career, one that's built on grit and determination, has no place for stereotypes - of any kind.
item.dc:creator: Laura House
item.mi:shortTitle: Actress Kiruna Stamell speaks out about smashing stereotypes

item.title: Feeling frosty? Customers are now paying $1 for fancy homemade ICE CUBES in upmarket city bars
item.description: Born in Japan, the trend for made to order 'designer ' ice has reached Perth, Western Australia. With cubes costing up to $1 each, would you pay extra for the ultimate in luxury drinking?
item.content:encoded:
When times are good, people are willing to pay serious cash for some of life's luxuries.

But where do you draw the line at excess?

In search of 'the perfect cocktail', Perth Now has reported that a select few bartenders in Western Australia have started to use 'made-to-order ice'.

Renowned for it's purity and crystal-like composition, Perth mixologists use the bespoke cubes as the secret ingredient to their refreshing creations.

The Western Australian hub is full to the brim with a whole host of small, high-end cocktail bars, and owners are not afraid of the added cost that comes with this rarefied clear ice.

Speaking to Perth Now, international beverage director of the Long Chim restaurant chain James Connolly says the ice 'adds wow factor and helps to make our bar offer a little special'.

The versatile product is suitable for use in any 'on the rocks' beverages, especially classic stirred drinks.

The trend first started with cocktail makers in Japan, where skilled bartenders crafted stunning shapes from simple ice to garnish glasses of premium vodka and prize whiskey. 

The use of these quirky, stylized cubes has quickly spread south to Australian venues in Perth, Melbourne and Sydney.

Made to order ice cubes can cost an exclusive establishment up to 90c each to purchase, due to the time and precise effort it takes to cut and shape the tiny blocks.

So would you pay the extra cash for designer 'cubes?
item.dc:abstract: In search of 'the perfect cocktail', a select few bartenders in Perth, Western Australia have started to use 'made-to-order ice'. Renowned for it's purity and crystal-like composition, Perth mixologists use the bespoke cubes (like the ones at Long Chim establishment, pictured) as the secret ingredient to their refreshing creations. The trend first started with cocktail makers in Japan, where skilled bartenders crafted stunning shapes from simple ice to garnish glasses of premium vodka and prize whiskey. Speaking to Perth Now, international beverage director of the Long Chim restaurant chain James Connolly says the ice 'adds wow factor and helps to make our bar offer a little special'.
item.dc:creator: Laura House
item.mi:shortTitle: How much would you pay for 'bespoke' ice cubes?

item.title: Celebrity chef shares the secret to making the perfect cheese toastie - and the ingredients will surprise you
item.description: Australian celebrity chef Justine Schofield has shared her delicious recipe to create the perfect cheese toastie in your kitchen.
item.content:encoded:
There are many different methods of making a humble cheese toastie.

And Australian celebrity chef Justine Schofield has shared her recipe to create the perfect cheese toastie in your kitchen.

Here, the former MasterChef contestant revealed the secret ingredients to perfecting the art of making deliciously grilled buttery bread with gooey, melted cheese.

Scroll down for recipe

'I love a Croque Monsieur - the king of all toasted sandwiches,' she told Daily Mail Australia ahead of the Kurrajong Kitchen Cheese Lovers Festival in Sydney.

'My secret ingredients… nutmeg and Dijon mustard. They pair beautifully with nutty cheeses.' 

When making the cheese toastie, the Everyday Gourmet host starts by preparing the Béchamel sauce.

On medium heat, Justine melts the butter before adding the flour and incorporating well by stirring for one minute to form a roux.

Next, she adds the milk little by little, whisking constantly until there are no lumps. Bring to the boil and then remove from the heat.

The she adds gruyere, mustard, nutmeg, salt and pepper. Once the mixture has cooled, she adds the yolk as she seasons to taste.

Placing slices of the sourdough on the bake tray, she spreads the béchamel sauce thickly on one side - and reserving a few tablespoons for later. 

Assembling the sandwich, Justine layers the side with ham before adding the remaining grated cheese and the closes the bread.

Heating the extra butter in a large frying pan, she adds the sandwiches and cooks until golden brown on each side.

Place back on the tray, and add the remainder béchamel and cheese. Place the toastie under the grill under the cheese is bubbling and melted.

Justine will be hosting cooking workshops and judging competitions at the Kurrajong Kitchen Cheese Lovers Festival on June 16.

For more details about the annual cheese festival, please visit the website.

How to make a Croque Monsieur

Ingredients 

Method 

Pre heat grill in the oven.

Melt the butter in a saucepan on medium heat. Once melted, add the flour and incorporate well by stirring for 1 minute to form a roux. Add the milk little by little, whisking constantly until there are no lumps. Bring to the boil and then remove from the heat.

Add 1/2 the cheese, mustard and nutmeg, salt and pepper. Once cooled slightly, add the yolk and mix well. Season to taste.

Place slices of the sourdough on the baking tray and spread the béchamel mixture thickly on one side (reserve a few tablespoons for later) and then add ham. Now add the remaining grated cheese and top with the bread.

Heat the extra butter in a large frying pan on medium to low heat. Add the sandwiches and cook until golden brown on each side (2-3 minutes). 

Place back on the tray and add the remainder béchamel and cheese. Place under the grill until the cheese is bubbling and melted.

Here, the former MasterChef contestant revealed the secret ingredients to perfecting the art of making deliciously grilled buttery bread with gooey, melted cheese.

item.title: 'I eat burgers and treats EVERY day': Fitness star Sarah Stevenson, 25, shares the surprisingly tasty diet she swears by to stay lean and keep her acne at bay
item.description: Sarah Stevenson, from Sydney, started her Youtube channel in a bid to help young women address their acne concerns - having been a sufferer herself.
item.content:encoded:
Sarah Stevenson started her YouTube channel in a bid to help young women address their acne concerns - having been a sufferer herself.

But since clearing her skin she has become a nutritional guru, with the Sydney-based fitness star an avid supporter of wholefoods and no-fuss meals.

In her latest video the 25-year-old explained how the food she puts into her body maintains her glowing complexion and why 'treats' can be good for you. 

Scroll down for video 

She starts her day at 7am with a glass of warm lemon water, a well-known trick to kick starting the metabolism and flushing out toxins.

Before her morning workout Sarah eats either an organic banana or apple and fills up her 2.2 litre water bottle to sip on during the day.

Once she returns from a sweaty HIIT-based workout or walk along the beach she'll tuck into a superfood smoothie.

Using a banana, coconut yoghurt for a healthy source of fat, Tropeaka lean protein in chocolate, maca powder to boost skin health, camu powder for vitamin C and cacao nibs the Sutherland Shire local whips up a tasty dessert brekkie in her Nutribullet.

She'll follow that with either a handful of fruit and nut mix or a protein ball.

For lunch Sarah prepares baked sweet potato with coconut oil, tumeric and salt and pepper to be added into a tasty tuna salad later on.

That leafy salad or 'nourish bowl' is filled with baby spinach, cucumber, a tablespoon of tahini, flaxseed oil, snow peas, tomato, pumpkin, sweet potato and tuna.

When 3pm hits and she becomes 'the sugar monster' it's straight to the cupboard for a bowl of chocolate buckini's, fruit and nut mix and almond milk.

For dinner Sarah craved a burger and decided to make one with a plantbased meat substitute and bun.

She made her own chickpea patty and added toppings of avocado, spinach, lemon, tomato, beetroot and tahini dressing. 

Sarah, who started her Youtube channel while she was suffering from severe acne, has previously outlined how she helped tame her oily skin.

'I use Vanity Planet's spin brush on my face with the silicon add-on to remove any build up on my face and cleanse using the Gentle Cleansing Gel by ASAP,' she revealed.

'They're nice and gentle on my skin but it also cleans it. When you're doing it, focus on areas that are problematic for you - so for me it's my nose.'  

Sarah follows her cleanse by applying the ASAP B serum, which she has been using for more than a year, and then either the Kiehl's Daily Reviving Concentrate or Adore Lifestyle Serum.

She explained that for her acne-prone skin, applying natural oils like rosehip and jojoba just 'break me out' and encourages others to research their skin type before putting on a product.

item.title: Are these the most amazing linen cupboards ever? Homeowners share snaps of their immaculately organised spaces - and reveal how you can transform your closet from drab to fab
item.description: Proud homeowners around Australia have showed off snaps of their immaculately organised linen cupboards - and their tips for transforming your space from drab to fab. FEMAIL takes a look.
item.content:encoded:
For many, a tidy home equals a tidy mind.

But there's neat and organised and then there's something that is much more aesthetically appealing.

Recently, proud homeowners around Australia showed off snaps of their immaculately organised linen cupboards - and how they got them into that state - via an interiors Facebook group. 

Many of them also shared their tips and tricks for transforming your cupboard from drab to fab.

'Can we start a linen cupboard thread. I need to get mine sorted and [am] seeking inspiration,' one woman posted on the From Great Beginnings group, to the tune of hundreds of comments and photos.

Some wrote that they swear by grey baskets from popular discount store, Kmart, while another user said a neat and well-ordered linen cupboard is all about investing in several $39 gliders and baskets from Howard's Storage World:

'Although [they are] not as pretty as most it's practical and works well. All the baskets... slide out for easy access,' she explained.

All you need to do is attach the baskets and gliders together for a simple system that allows you to view what's inside your closet with ease.

Top tips for making your linen cupboard organised 

1. Try to keep your towels either all one colour or similar colours to make things look neater.

2. Include a small diffuser or bouquet of flowers inside your cupboard to give your sheets and linen that 'just washed' scent.

3. Invest in some neutral-coloured boxes in either black, white, beige or light brown - Kmart does good boxes - and use them to store some linen.

4. Watch YouTube tutorials to teach yourself how to fold your towels like they do in the hotels.

5. Fold your sheets and put the pillowcases inside to keep things neat.

6. Roll hand washers and face towels as it looks neater than keeping them folded.

7. Buy baskets and gliders from somewhere like Howard's Storage in order to be able to see everything at a glance. 

Others shared photographs of their colour-coordinated cupboards, with neat and tidy Sheridan towels stacked on top of one another.

Some even stored bouquets of flowers inside their cupboard to help their linen smell fresh.

Adelaide-based interiors blogger Iryna Federico previously shared how she gets that 'just-washed' scent on her towels and sheets.

'Put a diffuser in there - I found a tiny "fresh linen" diffuser at Target and it smelled heavenly,' she told FEMAIL.

'The scent gets absorbed into the fabric and makes everything smell freshly washed even if it was cleaned months ago.'

Meanwhile, another homeowner shared her tried-and-tested tips to get your linen cupboard looking Pinterest-worthy in no time:

'Have towels the same colour or like colours,' she said. 'Buy some neutral-coloured boxes in either black, white, beige or light brown.

'Kmart has some nice industrial-looking fake wood boxes. You can keep some or all of your linen inside them.'

The user also recommended following YouTube tutorials on folding towels and linen.

'You can learn to fold towels like they do at the hotels, and roll face washers and put in a shallow box with the towels standing up.'

Another user said that whenever they fold their sheets, they put the matching pillowcases inside:

'It keeps them neat and they don't get mixed up,' they said.  

Among her other tips, Iryna Federico said it pays to throw out or re-purpose 'old and crusty towels' or teach all members of the household to fold towels in exactly the same way.

'Figure out the best and easiest way to fold them so they fit the dedicated space nicely,' she explained.   

Iryna also stressed the importance of rolling hand towels and face washers as it looks the best and eliminates the need for folding and utilising baskets for organisation.

Have you got a perfectly-organised linen cupboard? Email FemailAU@mailonline.com
item.dc:abstract: For many, a tidy home equals a tidy mind. But there is neat and organised and then there's something much more aesthetically appealing. Recently, proud homeowners around Australia showed off snaps of their immaculately organised linen cupboards (left, right and inset) - and shared their tips and tricks for transforming your space. Here, FEMAIL takes a look at how you can turn your cupboard from drab to fab.

item.title: From a tapas-loving catering company boss to a sports physio who's VERY popular with her clients: Meet the glamorous WAGs cheering on the Socceroos as they head to Russia for the World Cup
item.description: The Soceroos have landed in Russia ahead of their first World Cup Game From a catering company owner to a former Britain's Next Top Model contestant: meet the Socceroo WAGS.
item.content:encoded:
The Socceroos have landed in Russia with tens of thousands of green and gold fans ahead of their first World Cup Game against France on Saturday.

But they will be supported by their wives, girlfriends and families during the world's biggest sporting jamboree. 

From a catering company owner to a former Britain's Next Top Model contestant: meet the Socceroo WAGs cheering on their partners.

Dani Jones (Brad Jones)

Physiotherapist Dani Lawrence, who appeared on the 2007 series of Britain's Next Top Model, married goalkeeper Brad Jones in Cheshire,  England in 2015.

The pair met in 2008 when Dani, 31, was working as a physio for the youth team at Middlesbrough where Feyenoord keeper Jones, 36, played until 2010.

She once admitted the teenage boys often 'pretended' to be injured so they could see her and joked: 'Everyone used to say the clinic got busier when I was in.'

The pair have a son Nico, six, and a four-year-old daughter named Romi. 

In 2011, Brad lost his firstborn child Luca, from a previous relationship, who was just six at the time, after an 18-month battle with acute myeloid leukemia.

Even though Luca was from Brad's previous relationship, Dani said she struggled with a mix of guilt and joy when their first child Nico was born.

Natalie Jedinak (Mile Jedinak)  

Natalie Peacock married Aston Villa midfielder Mile Jedinak in 2010. The pair met when she was modelling in Sydney.

The blonde bombshell now lives with Jedinak and their three children in the UK.

They welcomed their son Andre in November 2011, the second son Alex was born in August 2013, and Leo James born in May 2017.

Rebekah Cahill (Tim Cahill)

Rebekah Greenhill married her childhood sweetheart Tim - Australia's former captain and most famous player - in 2010.  

The couple have four children: Sons Kyah, 15, Shae 13, and Cruz, six, and a daughter Sienna, 11.

The Cahills have homes in Sydney, Florida, New York, Shanghai, and England.

But unlike some of the other WAGs who love to flaunt their wealth, Rebekah is more camera shy.

When asked how he and Rebekah have avoided becoming like 'flashy couples' such as Posh and Becks, Tim said: 'I respect my wife's decision to do – or not do – as much as she wants. It's a simple life and we like it like that.' 

Ebony Risdon (Josh Risdon)

Businesswoman Ebony Tolcon married defender Risdon, 25, in May 2017.

She founded catering company Tapas Addict, which provides gourmet grazing tables at events such as weddings.

The pair met in Western Australia when Risdon was playing for Perth Glory and Ebony was working on getting her business off the ground.

After their marriage, he posted on Instagram: 'Without a doubt the best day of my life! Such an amazing day marrying my best friend.' 

Elissa Sainsbury (Trent Sainsbury)  

Elissa Sainsbury married defender Trent, 25, in December 2017. Her father Graham Arnold is the Sydney FC coach.

The pair were dating when Sainsbury won the league title with the Central Coast Mariners in 2013, coached by her father, who would four years later become his father-in-law.

Elissa moved to China with Trent when he signed for Jiangsu Suning but he's now on loan at Swiss team Grasshopper Club Zürich. 

His Instagram is full of gushing posts about her. In one he jokes, 'I'm a defender and she's a keeper.' 

Nicola Mooy (Aaron Mooy)

Nicola is married to Huddersfield midfielder Aaron, 27.

The pair met when he was playing for Western Sydney Wanderers in 2011. They now live in England with their daughter Skylar.  

Last year, Nicola wrote a gushing Instagram post about her husband in which she said: 'Love this man more than anything (apart from our wee Skye of course) I've watched him grow from a boy to a man and seeing him flourish as a dad and in his career is just truly admirable ! No matter what the future holds we will always support and love one another xxxxx'
item.dc:abstract: The Socceroos have landed in Russia with tens of thousands of green and gold fans ahead of their first World Cup Game against France on Saturday. But they will be also supported by their their wives, girlfriends and families during the world's biggest sporting jamboree. From a catering company owner to a former Britain's Next Top Model contestant: meet the Socceroo WAGS cheering on their husbands. Left to right: Nicola Mooy, Dani Jones, Ebony Risdon.

item.title: Un-pho-gettable recipes! Celebrity chefs reveal how they transform instant noodles into incredible gourmet meals including pancakes, pizza and toasties
item.description: Most university students or time-poor parents remember reaching for a packet of instant noodles on days they're looking for a quick dinner fix - but these Aussie chefs have made classier versions.
item.content:encoded:
Most university students or time-poor parents remember reaching for a packet of instant noodles on days when they're looking for a quick dinner fix.

But it turns out even celebrity chefs aren't immune to the tasty flavour sachets and have dreamed up a number of gourmet varieties of the simple meal.

Take Dan Hong, for example.

He's the Head Chef at Mr Wong and in between incredibly long shifts and creating decadent morsels of Asian fusion he's putting together the perfect noodle toastie.

'Cook instant noodles, then drain, add flavour sachet. Add chopped frankfurts or any leftover meat, and some chopped kimchi,' he told The Daily Telegraph.

'Put it between two slices of bread with whatever leftover cheese there is, then butter heavily. Put in jaffle maker or toasted sandwich press.'

The delicious snack may require a few more steps, but nothing the average home cook can't achieve with a spare ten minutes and leftover ingredients.

Head Chef at Stokehouse Ollie Hansford takes things one step further with the curation of instant noodle pancakes.

Not unlike the fluffy, buttery kind, Mr Hansford still mixes a light pancake batter to start, before adding the blanched noodles with 'peas, sweet corn, chilli, ginger, garlic and some kimchi.'

Once fried they take the shape of a large oval and can be eaten mess-free on the couch.

Chris Yan is a huge fan of the $2 noodle packets, incorporating them into his diet once or twice a week.

The Head Chef at Lotus Dining said he prefers them made into a hearty soup - the perfect addition to any winter meal.

'I'll usually make a soup by boiling the noodles, adding an egg, preserved vegetable oil, sesame oil and roasted sesame seeds,' he told the publication.

In one of the strangest additions to the list owner and Head Chef of Anason and Efendy, Somer Sivrioglu, eats his noodles with a side of yoghurt.

'I always cook them in leftover chicken or vegetable stock. Skip the MSG packet and instead add pepper paste, which is much healthier and delicious. I also love having them with homemade yogurt - we eat yogurt with everything and go through four to five kilos every week,' he explained.  

Instant noodles in a burrito, in a crunchy chicken salad and as the 'bun' on a burger have also made an appearance online to much fanfare.

But you won't want to eat them too regularly, with The George Institute for Global Health reporting on how unhealthy a typical pack can be.

Salt levels in Australian instant noodles were the second highest internationally with an average packet containing more than 80 per cent of the daily recommended maximum salt intake of five grams a day. 

That's more than eight small packets of Smith's salted crisps and two Big Macs.
item.dc:abstract: Most university students or time-poor parents remember reaching for a packet of instant noodles on days they're looking for a quick dinner fix. But it turns out even celebrity chefs aren't immune to the tasty flavour sachets and have dreamed up a number of gourmet varieties of the simple meal. Among them are a toastie (top left), soup (bottom left), pancake (top right) and even noodle dish with yoghurt as a base (bottom right).
