item.title: Utilise your commute and take 'workout breaks': How to work 30 minutes of exercise into your daily routine - without heading to the gym
item.description: As life gets busier, our fitness is often the first thing to fall by the wayside. The Australian Dept of Health warns we should be getting more exercise - but where can we find the time?
item.content:encoded:
These days, 'being busy' is regarded as a sign of success.

As our schedules fill up back-to-back with meetings, personal appointments, coffee catch-ups and school drop-offs, a hectic lifestyle is almost worn as a badge of honour.

Time for ourselves, both physical and mental, is often way down at the bottom of this growing list of priorities, and exercise can fall by the wayside to make room for other commitments. 

But experts warn that there can be a heavy price to pay for skipping your daily jog or yoga class - and it could come at a heavier cost to your health than you bargained for. 

According to the Department of Health, adults should engage in 30 - 40 minutes of moderate exercise every day to take care of your fitness and well being - that amounts to roughly 300 minutes or five hours per week. 

The government body also recommends that adults do some form of muscle strengthening activity twice weekly. 

Meeting these target advisories means that we are reducing our risk of chronic disease, including cancer, heart conditions and type 2 diabetes, lowering our blood pressure, reducing the risk of mental disorders such as depression and dementia and keeping our body weight down. 

That's a whole lot of reasons to get moving.  

To help you stay on top of the fitness game while continuing to live your best life, we've put together a list of our favourite subtle adjustments from the fitness coaches at Nine.com.au that you can make to your daily routine to incorporate more movement - without compromising your free time!

Two-for-one: Workout with a friend

While the obvious choice for a catch up with your best friend might be coffee, dinner or a few fancy cocktails, why not pair up as workout buddies?

Going to an exercise class or simply walking together makes you more likely to stick to your fitness routine, because let's face it we are less likely to bail on body weight squats if we have another person to do it with.

Exercising with a friend gives you that much needed time together while doing something productive for both of you and keeping one another motivated.  

It's the little things

Coming out of the office frazzled after a long day at work, the last thing we want to do is change into gym gear and hop on the treadmill for an hour.

To maximise your opportunities for movement during the day, make simple adjustments like taking the stairs instead of always pressing the elevator button.

Getting off the bus or train one stop earlier gives you time to do some gentle cardio before a busy day, which helps to set you up mentally for the challenges ahead too.

Take a stroll for fifteen minutes at lunch to get some much-needed fresh air and clock up invaluable exercise time all at once. Your body will thank you in the long run!

 Work towards a goal

Having a specific aim in mind makes it easier to do everything, whether it's saving money for your dream holiday or improving your fitness.

Set yourself a deadline by signing up for a 5k charity race or a triathlon.

Simply having a target in the calendar will instantly make you more motivated and give you that added push to work out even when you don't feel like it. 

Become 'exercise efficient'

If we were all truly honest with ourselves, most of us would admit that we make excuses to get out of exercising. 

We do have the time, even if it is just 30 minutes before work or in the evenings at the weekend.

If we can binge watch Netflix series for hours on end, we can make time to move!

Not every work out has to be a lengthy session - trying out quick HIIT plans or circuit training means you can get the most out of a shorter window of time and free up more time for leisure.

Don't forget to have fun!

If all workout sessions are gruelling, tortuous experiences engaging in exercises that we just don't enjoy, who could blame us for prioritising everything else above breaking a sweat?

Bring some fun back into your exercise routine by signing up for a step class, dancing lessons or synchronised swimming - whatever works for you!

Incorporating activities that get you excited will make you far more likely to commit to your fitness.
item.dc:abstract: These days, 'being busy' is regarded as a sign of success. As our schedules fill up back-to-back with meetings, personal appointments, coffee catch-ups and school drop-offs, a hectic lifestyle is almost worn as a badge of honour. Time for ourselves, both physical and mental, is often way down at the bottom of this growing list of priorities, and exercise can fall by the wayside to make room for other commitments. But as the Australian Department of Health warns that all adults should engage in at least 30 minutes of moderate exercise every day, it seems more important than ever to make time for our bodies. FEMAIL knows that it can be a challenge to 'do it all' without sacrificing quality time with friends, families and significant others. To help you stay on top of the fitness game while continuing to live your best life, we've put together a list of our favourite subtle adjustments from the fitness coaches at Nine.com.au that you can make to your daily routine to incorporate more movement - without compromising your free time!

item.title: 'I was 100kg at 12 years of age': Woman, 28, who hit 170 kilos loses HALF her body weight after junk food addiction left her in fear for her life
item.description: Laura Jade Bates, from Central Coast in NSW, lived off an unhealthy diet where she was gorging on fast foods and snacks - a lifestyle that saw her tip the scales at a staggering 170kg.
item.content:encoded:
A 28-year-old woman who was addicted to food has dramatically lost more than half her body weight in an astonishing transformation.

Laura Jade Bates, from Central Coast in NSW, lived off an unhealthy diet where she was gorging on fast foods and snacks - a lifestyle that saw her tip the scales at a staggering 170kg.

At her heaviest, Laura said she wore size 28 clothing, endured pain in her back and knee joints - and she even struggled to find work because she was morbidly obese.

But after imagining what her life would be like in her 30s, she realised she needed to focus on her health because she knew she wouldn't reach that stage.

'I literally had a "light bulb moment" where I had just had enough of being this way. Hitting 170kg on the scales definitely scared me,' she told Daily Mail Australia.

'I was only 23 at the time. I tried to imagine my life in my 30s and truthfully if I had kept up the way I was going, I doubt I would've made it there.'

Before embarking on her weight loss journey, Laura - who documents her journey on Instagram - said she had an unhealthy relationship with food since birth.

'I had a bad relationship with food. Happy? I ate. Sad? I ate. Bored? I ate. Celebrating? I ate. I didn't even need a reason,' she said.

'It's funny looking back and thinking about it because hunger would've been the last reason I ate. Although I don't think I ever let myself get hungry.

'Fast food was what I mainly ate. Purely out of convenience and that I could eat it in my car without anyone seeing me. Potato chips and lollies, all sorts of junk.

'Is emotional binge eating a thing? If so, that would describe me perfectly. Eating could've been considered my hobby. It's really no surprise why I ended up 170kg.'

For most of her life, Laura - who is a full time carer for her grandmother - said her weight spiralled out of control since she was a baby.

'I was 100kg at 12 years of age. I honestly don't know how I let myself get so big. Even though it's me, I look at old photos of myself and I can't believe it,' she said.

'Family and friends say the same because I said to them "how did you guys never say anything to me?" and they all say the same thing - "we didn't see you as big as you were".'

Laura made a heartbreaking admission that one of the main challenges she faced was trying to land a job.

'During school I was lucky enough to not be bullied but my main challenges I was faced with was when I was older trying to gain employment,' she said.

'Hairdressing was always something I wanted to do, it still is and is definitely something I want to pursue. But being morbidly obese, I couldn't get a job.

'I know appearance shouldn't come into it - but of course it does, especially one that requires you to be on your feet all day.'

Growing up, Laura said she knew from an early age her size was different from other children.

'I struggled with my weight since I came out of the womb pretty much. I was a big baby, toddler, kid, teenager and adult,' she said, laughing.

'I was tested for genetic disorders at two years old. It wasn't until I was around 13 where I was diagnosed with Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome and insulin resistance. 

'I'm not one to play the genetics card because I don't blame that 100 per cent but it definitely contributed to my struggles.'

Astonishingly, Laura said she hardly suffered from any health problems but she started hating herself because of her size.

'When I was at my heaviest, that was at a time when I was on antidepressants and they pretty much made me feel nothing,' she said. 

'I was obviously sad, depressed and hated myself. No one gets to that size with self-love. Physically I was sore and tired.

'I was one of those people who because my blood tests were fine and I didn't have diabetes - I considered myself healthy. Well as healthy as someone could be at that size. I didn't have high blood pressure or cholesterol... yet. 

'It was of course inevitable. But what did start happening is just because of the pure weight of my body, my knees and back started to give in. That was actually more scary for me.' 

Over the course of two years, Laura said she managed to lose almost 60kg naturally. But after injuring her back, she gained 40kg in a short amount of time.

'Just how easy it was to gain all that back and undo my hard work in such a short time frame absolutely crushed me,' she said.

And so, determined to lose weight once and for all, Laura turned to a mini gastric bypass surgery in May 2017.

'I went from 170kg to 110kg naturally, regained back to 152.5kg and since surgery I'm down to 83.7kg. Overall I've lost 86.3kg which still blows my mind,' she said.

'I know a couple of kg's here and there is normal but I won't ever let myself become obese again.'

Looking at old pictures of herself, Laura admits she still sees herself at her heaviest.

'As crazy as it is, I still sometimes look in the mirror and see my 170kg self looking back at me,' she said.

'To someone who hasn't experienced such drastic weight loss, you'd think I was crazy. But it actually happens to most, dare I say, all of us. 

'I don't think it'll all sink in until after I undergo my skin removal surgery which will be happening at the end of this year.'

More than a year since her surgery, Laura - who trains up to six days a week - said she tries to maintain a healthy diet.

'I'm definitely still not the epitome of health. Trying to change and rewire 25 years of eating complete garbage is hard,' she said.

'I'm still not a fan of vegetables - I'm like a kid having to grate them up and hide them in meals. Because of my operation, pieces of red meat don't really sit well with me so I tend to go for mince, chicken, yogurt, protein bars/shakes, Cruskits with peanut butter or hummus and nuts.

'I don't really have a wide range of meal options, I tend to stick with the same few things that I know I like.'

By sharing her extraordinary story, Laura - who went from a size 26-28 to a size 14 after slimming down to 83.7kg - wanted other people to draw from her experiences.

'I still even now don't feel like I have my s*** together. I take it one day at a time. Some days I'm super motivated, then there's others where I'm just sick of thinking about it,' she said, laughing. 

'I know it's not exactly helpful, but at the end of the day no one can do it for you. You have to want it.

I know people tend to say that weight loss surgery is the easy way out - I hate to admit that I was one of those people. It couldn't be further from the truth. Unless you've been morbidly obese, you don't have any idea what it's like

'The road hasn't been easy and its been extremely up and down not just weight wise but emotionally. 

'I know it's always going to be something I will have to deal with and struggle with which is why I will never regret my decision to undergo weight loss surgery. I knew I was fighting a losing battle so I got this to help me take control of my life.

'I know people tend to say that weight loss surgery is the easy way out - I hate to admit that I was one of those people. It couldn't be further from the truth.

'Unless you've been morbidly obese, you don't have any idea what it's like.'

For confidential support, please Lifeline Australia - 13 11 14.
item.dc:abstract: A 28-year-old woman who was addicted to food has dramatically lost more than half her body weight in an astonishing transformation. Laura Jade Bates, from Central Coast in NSW, lived off an unhealthy diet where she was gorging on fast foods and snacks - a lifestyle that saw her tip the scales at a staggering 170kg. At her heaviest, Laura said she wore size 28 clothing, endured pain in her back and knee joints - and she even struggled to find work because she was morbidly obese.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Tran
item.mi:shortTitle: Woman, 28, who weighed 170kg loses HALF her body weight

item.title: 'I prayed for a water bottle or a cup': Mother-of-two hilariously recounts using her toddler's NAPPIES to relieve herself when she couldn't find a desperately needed public toilet
item.description: A Melbourne mother-of-two has revealed just how she coped when the urge to go to the bathroom struck when she was out and about. She shares the most 'mortifying moment' she can remember.
item.content:encoded:
A mother-of-two has revealed how she coped after she was struck by a desperate urge to use the loo while out and about with her toddler – and the embarrassing act she was forced into when one couldn't be found.

Adele Barbaro, from Melbourne, who blogs about motherhood under The Real Mumma, recently shared details about the incident, one she described as the 'most mortifying but relieving moment' she can remember.

'The day a grown woman filled three toddler nappies,' the embarrassed mum wrote.

Setting the scene, the 35-year-old mum explained how she had taken her daughter Chloe out to feed the ducks when she was hit with a desperate urge to go to the loo.

The mum said while this wasn't something that normally happened, she had started drinking as much as three litres of water a day and as a result needed to go to the toilet more often.

'As I drove away from home, I realised I hadn't been to the loo, which is usually part of my leaving the house routine. But I didn't feel like I needed to go, so I carried on.' 

Adele said not long after arriving at the park she 'realised a wee was coming' but rather than pack everything back in the car and turn around, she decided to look for a toilet on the walking track.

'So I popped her in the stroller and off we went.'

She said despite being absolutely certain there were public toilets she couldn't find one anywhere.

'As we came around the bend. No loos. I could have sworn had seen a public toilet block but it was some kind of storage shed instead,' she said. 

'And with that, I realised I was in trouble.'

She said in her desperation, she thought about going in the bushes.

'I nearly did but bike riders would come out of nowhere or the footy team would conveniently stop and stretch.'

After realising there was nothing for it but to turn about and head back to her car, Adele said she did all she could to stop herself from going including 'motivational head talk'.

She said by this time her need to go was so great, her only option was to use anything she had to hand. 

'I prayed for a water bottle or a cup or anything floating around in the car. I was actually in pain.

'I got to the car and like that, I couldn't hold anymore. 

'The effort to open the car door and search for something to pee in took away from my efforts to hold the litre of water in my bladder and it started coming out.'

'I flipped open the glove box and saw there was a bunch of spare nappies for Harvey.

'I flared one open, shoved it down my pants and like that, I sat in my car, slowly peeing into my sons nappy while Chloe looked at me bewildered.'

She said even though there was a hockey game in progress, she just sat in the car 'pretending to watch'.

'I learnt when I went for pregnancy ultrasounds that you could stop peeing at any time if you needed to and with this new skill, I stopped, removed the nappy, put another on and continued what was the most mortifying but relieving moment I can remember.

'And that day was the day a grown woman filled three toddler nappies.'

Naturally, Adele's many thousands of followers found the post hilarious, with many also sharing their own tales of bathroom desperation.

One woman, Cherice wrote: 'Been there done that... mine was in a shopping centre parking lot. When I knew I wouldn't be able to get out of the car, get the pram and my daughter out and find a toilet in time.'

While others said how thankful they were for the resourceful 'hack':

'This is actually genius. Haha. I would have got caught peeing in the bushes if it were me thanks for sharing.'
item.dc:abstract: A Melbourne mother-of-two, Adele Barbaro (left and right) has revealed just how she coped when the urge to go to the bathroom struck when she was out and about. She described the moment, one that saw her needing to improvise with nappies as 'most mortifying but relieving moment I can remember.'

item.title: Revealed: Elle Macpherson, 54, shares her sure-fire method for banishing her 'muffin top' - and the secret she uses to get those perfect abs
item.description: Supermodel and wellness entrepreneur, Elle Macpherson, has lifted the lid on her health secrets - revealing the one thing that helped her to banish her 'muffin top' at 54, and the secret to perfect abs.
item.content:encoded:
With glowing skin and the nickname 'The Body', Elle Macpherson has a global following who hang off her every word in their quest to live a little more like hers.

And now, the supermodel and wellness entrepreneur has lifted the lid on her health secrets - revealing the one thing that has helped her to banish her 'muffin top' at the age of 54, and the secret to perfect abs.

Speaking to Get The Gloss, Elle explained that the secret to a trim and toned mid-section is giving up sugar.

'Sugar is highly addictive - it's very hard to give up,' Elle explained in a video shared on the site.

'I'm less interested in my silhouette than I am about the way I feel. 

'But fortunately, the by product of looking after myself from a nutritional point of view is that my skin is better, my shape is better, I'm stronger, I'm happier, I have less sugar cravings and I've lost weight from places that were really difficult to lose weight from - like the muffin top.'   

Now, Elle substitutes the sugar that comes from things like pasta and white bread for 'a few cubes of 80 to 90 per cent dark chocolate', cacao and Super Elixir Nourishing Protein Powder in either vanilla or chocolate flavour. 

She also makes sure she drinks plenty of water, gets between eight and nine hours sleep a night and follows a predominantly plant-based diet.

So what does a day on Elle Macpherson's sugarless plate generally look like?

The supermodel explained that on any given day, she will focus on plant-based foods and an alkaline approach - which has helped her feel better than ever:

'Today, I made some protein balls with protein powder, which I enjoyed with Super Elixir this morning.

'I then had a power bowl for lunch - filled with some quinoa, broccoli, asparagus and kale, and I'm about to have another Super Elixir.'

If people want to eat animal protein, the model suggests either grass-fed beef or line-caught fish, which she'll generally enjoy in the evening with steamed greens.

'I also love a sleep tea with valerian,' she said - which she'll enjoy alongside her evening ritual of no screens and a period of being thankful.

Finally, Elle shared how she maintains balance, while juggling a well-being empire and ongoing modelling career.

'I think the biggest change I made was not picking up my phone first thing,' she said, adding that when you 'defer' that first screen moment, you have more time to be thankful and grateful for what you have.

Now, Elle gets up, puts on music in the house and gets her son breakfast, which they enjoy together.

She then drops him at school, comes back and goes for a walk or jog, and only then does she switch on her devices.

'If you can defer that phone moment or screen moment, it's so much easier to be present in the day,' she concluded.

To read more from Elle Macpherson, you can read her Body Blog here.

item.title: Taco salads, CHOCOLATE hummus and heavy weights: Model Natyse Chan, 20, shares the unique health regime she swears by for a flawless bikini body
item.description: At the ripe age of 20, blonde bombshell Natyse Chan, from the Gold Coast, has found her feet in the modelling world working with some of Australia's most iconic swimwear labels.
item.content:encoded:
At the ripe age of 20, blonde bombshell Natyse Chan has found her feet in the modelling world working with some of Australia's most iconic swimwear labels.

But when she's not in front of the camera the Gold Coast model is enjoying a number of unusual meals interspersed with group circuit training.

'For breakfast I always eat either protein porridge or have a smoothie with spinach, protein, oats, almond milk, 1/2 frozen banana and honey,' she told FEMAIL.

'Lunch will either be a salad or veggies and meat. I'm currently loving a "taco salad" which is essentially just a leafy base with shredded carrot, tomatoes, corn kernels, mushroom, cucumber, baked sweet potato, avocado and usually turkey mince cooked with salt-reduced taco seasoning. 

'Dinner is usually the same as lunch, because I don't like to keep food stored in the fridge for too long, so I'll normally eat the same meals until I run out and then I'll cook a different meal.'

She does admit to snacking throughout the day but it depends on what she has at home at any given time. 

'Snacks can vary depending on what I have at home. I love things like chopped up watermelon or grapes because I can easily pick at them throughout the day. I also love peanut butter with apple slices,' she said.

'I'm a major sweet tooth so nine times out of 10 there will be some form of chocolate lying around the house. I love making "chocolate hommus" (look it up on Pinterest) and dipping digestive biscuits into it. I tend to avoid full cream milk and cheese because it bloats me a lot.'

Natyse trains at a gym called PLC which is essentially a group circuit workout with 20-50 people in a class.  

'I love training in a big group of people because personally I find it motivating as I am quite a competitive person. I tried training in gyms by myself and found that I let myself off too easy and wasn't pushing myself enough,' she explained.

'Most of the sessions at PLC are a mix of HIIT and weights, with certain days targeting certain areas of the body (i.e. arm day, leg day ect). There are also a few days that are dedicated to slow and controlled heavy weight exercises, as well as boxing and yoga at the end of the week. 

'I try to train 5-6 days per week, first thing in the morning. However, sometimes I can't train because I'll be working and usually I don't have the energy to do a session at night after I finish.'

When asked about the best and worst aspects of her job, she was very honest in her approach.

While she 'can't imagine pursuing anything else right now', it does come with a whole new wave of confidence issues - particularly if you're having an 'off' day.  

'I personally put quite a lot of pressure on myself to try and be the best version of myself that I can be and that, for me, is super exhausting,' she said.

'Confidence is another thing that I know for a fact a lot of models struggle with. Everyone has those days when we are bloated or we are just simply not feeling ourselves and when you're a model sometimes your job will be to pose in front of a camera wearing bikinis all day, regardless of how you're feeling. 

'When you get a set of photos back and you don't like them or they didn't turn out how you had previous imagined then sometimes that can really take a toll on your confidence. 

'Also, rejection is another thing that comes with the job. I have been rejected more times then I can count and most of my rejection comes from the fact that I'm two inches too short for a lot of clients and agencies which is super unfortunate because my height is something that I can't change.'

She also looks at the 3am wake up calls, sore feet from standing in heels all day and sitting in airports for hours as frustrating parts of her work.    

'But I absolutely love modelling and the downsides have made me a stronger person and helped me develop a thicker skin,' the 20-year-old admitted.

item.title: A picture is worth a thousand words: What Kate's beaming smiles and £40 Zara dress tells us about her friendship with sister-in-law Meghan Markle
item.description: Is this, then, a snapshot of the real Kate, the way she sees herself, a royal duchess and a Middleton? And if so, why now? The answer lies in part with another set of pictures.
item.content:encoded:
Photographs seldom say too much, but once in a while they say everything. On Sunday afternoon the cameras clicked on a family relaxing in the sunshine at a polo match.

Naturally, the focus of this carefree sequence were the children, Prince George, four, and his three-year-old sister Princess Charlotte, the royal scene-stealer-in-chief.

For once, George, so often uncomfortable in the public gaze was a picture of playful intent, whether it was swiping a ball with his cut-down polo stick, playing make-believe cowboys or just obediently watching 'papa' Prince William on horseback.

But while the young Prince and his sister with her skipping and somersaults are certainly charming, the stand-out element of this tableau of family happiness is surely the children's mother.

Sitting bare-legged on the ground with sunglasses casually propped up on her head, they are the most extraordinary pictures of the Duchess of Cambridge. Extraordinary, because the way a woman looks usually reflects the way she feels.

And there can be no doubt that judging from her smiling informality, Kate is feeling wonderful.

Now there is surely something unexpected about this. It is, after all, only seven weeks since the birth of her third child, Prince Louis, and if the experience of her first-born children is anything to go by, the early weeks of baby No 3 have been tough.

George cried and was difficult to feed, and while Charlotte was perfect in comparison, her arrival left Kate exhausted, even irritable. With all three pregnancies she suffered from extreme morning sickness, so who could blame her if she wanted to retreat from the spotlight a little bit longer.

But look closely at the pictures and at the joie de vivre that shines out. No sign of resentment at being photographed — something she has displayed in the past — no suggestion of self-pity.

Instead, there is a radiance that says: 'Here I am, the happiest woman in the world.'

Is this, then, a snapshot of the real Kate, the way she sees herself, a royal duchess and a Middleton? And if so, why now? The answer lies in part with another set of pictures. These were taken 24 hours earlier, of the Buckingham Palace balcony for the Queen's official birthday celebrations, Trooping the Colour.

In these, the slim Duchess in a hat that seemed to elevate her height, stands in the front row next to her father-in-law Prince Charles, towering over him. She is looking completely at ease.

Behind her is the Duchess of Sussex, slimmer — and shorter — but in a dusty pink outfit that highlighted the honeymoon glow of her shoulders.

The two women, relatives by marriage and neighbours at Kensington Palace are the pin-ups of the Royal Family, both epitomes of style and whose every outfit provokes a sales rush.

When Harry and Meghan gave their post-engagement interview, the prince spoke of the challenge the actress set. As he recalled, he told himself: 'I am really going to have to up my game here.'

Harry, it seems, has not been the only one to up their game — in palace corridors they are saying that so, too, has the Duchess of Cambridge. Just take her clothes.

The casual dress she wore for the family visit to Beaufort Polo Club on Sunday that displayed her open neck owed much to the 'bateau'-style Meghan chose, not just for her wedding dress but also at Trooping. There is no doubt the couture chic of Meghan has drawn comparisons with Kate's more High Street look. In fact, the dress sense of both women is highly prized — but are they rivals?

Courtiers believe there could be a nuanced message here. As elegant and chic as Kate looked, her £39.99 Zara dress will be much more affordable to the average British woman than Meghan's high-end fashion choices.

There was surprise that Meghan chose the off-the-shoulder look again on Saturday. 'She looked like she was going to a cocktail party rather than the formality of the Queen's birthday parade,' says a former palace official.

'It's a difficult act to pull off, and these are early days, but maybe she's trying to be a little too cutting edge. In her early days, Kate had to be subtly told not to show so much leg, so it can happen to anyone.'

Many at the Palace have warmed to the arrival of the American for just those reasons, of course. Kate can come across as stiff and rather formal alongside the more spontaneous and articulate Meghan.

They are not the first royal sisters-in-law to face critical attention. Thirty years ago, Princess Diana and the Duchess of York see-sawed between kinship and rivalry. At first, the two were friends: Diana, remember, more or less introduced Sarah Ferguson into Prince Andrew's life and after the Yorks' wedding they became close friends.

But after five years of Diana, the public were bound to be intrigued by the new arrival. And they weren't alone. Charles famously once reproached his wife, saying: 'Why can't you be more like Fergie?'

The criticism stuck and Diana told photographers: 'You don't need me, you've got Fergie now.'

By the time of their separations they were reconciled, only to fall out again when Fergie brought out her memoirs. But this time there was no making up and Diana was dead before there could be a rapprochement.

Kate, of course is not Diana, though Sunday's visit to the polo field is so reminiscent of the Princess's own weekend visits with Harry and William to watch Prince Charles play in the Eighties and early Nineties.

And any comparison between the Duchess of Sussex and Fergie, starts and ends with the fact that Meghan, too, married a younger royal prince, who also happened to be in the armed services.

Meanwhile, her adjustment to royal life is taking time. Insiders say she was 'very nervous' on her first appearance on the Palace balcony and Harry was a reassuring presence at her side.

Both Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall have recognised that such is the scale of the change in her life from screen star to working duchess that she will need extra time to adapt.

'They are trying to keep things light to ensure she doesn't get overwhelmed by the idea of duty,' says a friend of the Prince. 'There are protocols to observe, but they are saying that things can be done differently and no one will really raise too much of an eyebrow.'

Kate can be key to this. As an outsider, she knows the royal ropes, but the two women are not obvious allies. What binds them is the love and affection they have for Harry and their shared lives at Kensington Palace.

There is one area where Meghan cannot compete with Kate — children. Harry yearns to become a father and the sight of George and Charlotte playing in the sunshine also carried a powerful message.

For Kate was showing that, as a member of the Royal Family, being a mother is the most important thing of all. So it may be that rather than Kate copying Meghan, Meghan will want to copy Kate.

item.title: Do only children REALLY grow up to be loners? One mother seems to thinks so - but what do the experts and 'lonely onlys’ make of their reputation
item.description: Thirty-one-year-old Hazel, an attractive and successful fitness instructor from Lancashire, wasn’t looking for love, she was happy with her boyfriend of a year: she was looking for friends.
item.content:encoded:
Like many modern women, Hazel Walsh turned to the internet when she wanted to meet someone special.

She signed up to an app and carefully sifted out those of a similar age and with whom she shared some common interests. Several weeks later, she found herself sitting in a coffee shop, counting down the minutes until she could make her excuses and go home.

Another bad dating story? Not so.

Thirty-one-year-old Hazel, an attractive and successful fitness instructor from Lancashire, wasn't looking for love — she was very happy with her boyfriend of a year: she was looking for friends.

She didn't have any (not close ones anyway), and as that awkward meet-up with other women in a similar situation proved, the social skills needed to set other women at ease, and relax and enjoy their company, just weren't there. And this, she is convinced, is a legacy of growing up an only child.

'My parents separated when I was four and Mum and I have been a little unit ever since,' says Hazel, who only last year moved out of her 56-year-old mother Shirley's home. 'We've done everything together, from losing weight to venturing into dating, and I wouldn't change our relationship for anything.

'But the older I get, the more conscious I am that I would love to have female friends my own age. Mum has always encouraged me to try to make friends, but I've never managed to form a bond with other girls because I've always been used to entertaining myself or to Mum entertaining me.

'Even at university, friendships were transient. I think if I'd had a sibling, I'd have been used to interacting with kids of my age and making friends would have been easier.'

Hazel's thoughts echo comments made recently by actress and model Liz Hurley, 52, who spoke of her regret at not having had another child as a sibling for her 16-year-old son Damian, whose father is U.S. businessman Steve Bing.

She implied that having a brother or sister would have helped her son develop social skills which can only be learned when you are part of a brood, saying: 'I was one of three: a big sister and a little brother to squabble with and to love.'

Today, due to a combination of late-life motherhood and the length of time it can take a couple to feel financially secure enough to start a family, more parents than ever are sticking at one child.

The number of single child families has grown by 12 per cent in the past decade, and more than half of all British families will have just one child by 2022.

The latest data from the Office for National Statistics shows that in 2016, 45 per cent of all families with dependent children (those aged under 16, or under 18 but still in education) had just one dependent child.

That compares with 42 per cent of families in 1996.

Meanwhile, 40 per cent of these families had two dependent children, and just 15 per cent had three or more.

Some critics have warned that Britain will become a country of 'little emperors' — a phrase coined in China, where the government's rule of one child for every couple has apparently produced millions of spoilt youngsters.

But there is a growing body of evidence to suggest that such assumptions about only children are ill thought through and not backed up by facts at all.

Many would argue, for example, that Hazel's social awkwardness might be due to growing up in a single parent household — although she always saw her dad at weekends — or that she might be genetically predisposed to being socially awkward.

Claire Hughes, professor of developmental psychology at Cambridge University and co-author of Why Siblings Matter, points out that there is a great deal of evidence from studies in China, suggesting that the negative effects of being an 'only one' are negligible.

She goes on to explain that it is down to good parenting to ensure that children — however many siblings they do or do not have — learn to interact with others in a positive manner.

'The key is not to be a 'snowplough parent' — don't work too hard at sweeping any problems out of their way,' she says.

'As with all children, sometimes it's good for things to be a bit awkward or inconvenient for them, because then they have to work out how to overcome troubles.

'Let's face it, it's not a given that a sibling relationship is going to be all sweetness and light. I know parents who have to separate their children at weekends — Mum takes one, and Dad takes the other — purely to stop them fighting.'

Sarah Ockwell-Smith, a mother-of-four and an only child herself, is the author of nine parenting titles, including The Gentle Parenting Book. She believes it to be wholly wrong to label or stereotype only children.

'All the research shows that our assumptions about being an only child aren't the reality,' she says. 'So, they are not less happy, they don't have more issues with friendships or with sharing and socialising.

'Whether you've got ten kids or one, they basically just need lots of love and support — and to be raised as individuals according to their character and interests. Only children who don't easily make friends would probably have struggled even if they did have siblings. It will just be part of their nature.'

This argument is borne out by 34-year-old Tom Murphy, a project manager from Hampshire, who grew up as an only child. He recalls how his mother 'devoted her life' to ensuring he grew up as a sociable boy surrounded by friends.

'She took me to every sporting activity going, including tennis and football, so I'm used to being part of a team and have never had a problem walking into social situations or making friends — yet I'd have loved to have had siblings.'

Today, he lives with his wife Hannah, director of a fitness company, and their three children aged nine, six and two, and says: 'I would never have entertained us having only one child.'

He says he became acutely aware of being an only child when he was aged five, and his parents took him to Ireland to stay with his aunt and uncle, who had seven children.

After that, he and his mother would spend every school summer holiday with them — and he loved nothing more than the cameraderie he experienced while spending time with his cousins.

'I remember always feeling huge disappointment when we went home at the end of the summer and there was no one for me to hang out with,' he reflects.

Professor Hughes says cousins can be crucial for only children when it comes to developing social skills: 'The relationship between single children and cousins is of real interest and doesn't get enough attention. I suspect this is where many only children find companionship in China.

'A study in Ireland, where children often grow up in close proximity to their cousins, even if they've got brothers and sisters, found that they act as surrogate siblings.

'There's the potential for the same level of familiarity between cousins as siblings, the same enduringness to the relationship, and the same vested interest in the family as a whole.'

Despite having cousins he is close to, Tom says his wife regularly accuses him of having what she terms 'only child syndrome'.

'I'm quite opinionated and don't tend to see other people's points of view,' he admits. 'I didn't have to learn to listen or negotiate.

'If I wanted to go to the park with my mother, that's where we'd go. But if I ask my chldren what they want to do, they all want different things so we have to compromise.

'I often have to go downstairs early in the morning to sort out a squabble over what they each want to watch on TV.'

Tom's father died when he was 15 and his mum died very suddenly three years ago. He confesses that being 'orphaned' has made him wish he had a sibling to share memories with and fall back on.

'It's the part of being an only child that I've found hardest,' he says. 'From the moment Mum died, I felt like I was really on my own. It still feels so lonely.

'My wife still has her parents and grandparents alive and hasn't experienced loss yet, so I don't have anyone to talk to about how it really feels.'

Teaching assistant Liz Handley, 39, shares Tom's sentiments. After her father died in 2005, she spent the next decade caring for her mother, who was diagnosed with early onset dementia. At the same time, she was juggling two young children of her own and says the stress of the situation was a factor in her marriage breaking down in 2009.

'I cannot describe the difference it would have made to have a sibling to support me and help make decisions about Mum's care,' says Liz, who lives near Birmingham with her children, who are now aged 17 and 13.

'As Mum's condition deteriorated, I struggled to cope. Then, after eight years of looking after her, making the decision to put her into a care home almost broke me.

'My friends were wonderful, telling me that it was absolutely the right — and safest — thing for Mum, and that her illness was so advanced that she wasn't aware of what was happening. Then, when she died in 2015, I struggled to cope with my grief. There was no brother or sister to share it with, someone who felt the same way about Mum as I did. When my daughter turned 13 recently, she asked me what I'd done on my 13th birthday. I didn't know — and didn't have anyone I could ask.'

Beauty consultant Rebecca Howard Dennis, 38, from Primrose Hill in London, however, says she is eternally grateful to her parents for sticking to one child, as it gave her the most wonderful childhood imaginable.

Because her parents didn't have to spread their attention or finances among several children, they were able to give Rebecca the best of everything, she says.

She was supported academically and won a place at the local all-girls' grammar school in Lincolnshire, and enjoyed exotic holidays around the world.

She also became the first person in her family to go to university, studying English literature at UCL in London.

'Mum and Dad gave me everything, but without spoiling me, and we travelled extensively when I was a child,' says Rebecca, who is married with two daughters aged seven and five.

'We went on a road trip around America, scuba diving in the Maldives, and had holidays in Canada and Morocco.

'Ultimately, it's thanks to my parents and to being an only child that I had the opportunity to study in London, then stay here and have the lovely life and career that I do.'

Rebecca admits that the subject of her being an only child is usually of more concern to other people, including her husband, a script writer, who is the youngest of three brothers.

'On one of our first dates, he quipped that he was used to getting his own way as the baby of the family and I replied, tongue in cheek, that I was an only child so he'd got nothing on me.

'But I'm honestly not like that at all. I was always a great sharer of toys and so on.

'People have preconceptions about only children being selfish and unsociable, which in my view are wholly naive and wrong.

'I'm often asked if I wish I'd had a sibling, and I'm sure I'd have loved one — but I don't recall ever longing for a brother or a sister. Mum miscarried two years after having me, so it wasn't to be.

'My parents are very much enjoying the fact that they are grandparents to two children, although they often comment, watching the girls fight, that they're relieved they never had do adjudicate over sibling squabbles.'

Having had Rebecca young, her parents are still only 61 and 66, so she has yet to deal with the one aspect of being an only child that is impossible to avoid — coping with their deaths in the absence of a sibling.

'I do worry that when they're no longer here, I will be utterly bereft. We're so close in life that in death it will be incredibly hard. Mum always says that having my own children will help to ease that.'
item.dc:abstract: Thirty-one-year-old Hazel, an attractive and successful fitness instructor from Lancashire, wasn’t looking for love — she was very happy with her boyfriend of a year: she was looking for friends. She didn’t have any (not close ones anyway), and as that awkward meet-up with other women in a similar situation proved, the social skills needed to set other women at ease, and relax and enjoy their company, just weren’t there. And this, she is convinced, is a legacy of growing up an only child. Left to right: Liz Handley, 39, Rebecca Howard Davis, 38, Tom Murphy, 34, Hazel Walsh, 31.
item.dc:creator: Alex Green
item.mi:shortTitle: Do only children REALLY grow up to be loners? One mother thinks so

item.title: Royal showoffs! Princess Olympia posts a VERY provocative selfie as she joins an A-list talent agency, while her cousin Talita von Furstenberg strikes a pose in two different bikinis in Greece
item.description: Princess Olympia of Greece, 21, took to Instagram on Monday to share a photo of herself modeling a skimpy cream slip, while Talita, 19, posted swimsuit photos of herself.
item.content:encoded:
Princess Olympia of Greece struck a sultry pose in a silk negligee before revealing she signed with Untitled Entertainment — the same agency that represents Jared Leto and Naomi Watts.

The 21-year-old royal took to Instagram on Monday to share a photo of herself lying on her bed with her head resting on her hand and one leg bent to show off the curve of her thigh.

'Morning,' she captioned the mirror selfie, which shows her modeling a skimpy cream slip.

Olympia also updated her Instagram bio so that it now lists her new agency, Untitled Entertainment, next to her name.

The management company founded by Jason Weinberg and Stephanie Simon represents a bevy of A-list clients, including Elizabeth Banks, Kate Hudson, Ashton Kutcher, and Olivia Wilde.

While Olympia was celebrating her foray into the entertainment industry, her cousin Princess Talita von Furstenberg was enjoying some fun in the sun in Greece.

The 19-year-old granddaughter of designer Diane von Furstenberg shared an Instagram photo of herself modeling a patterned string bikini while leaning against a stone wall overlooking the blue sea below her.

When captioning the image, she shared three Greek flag emoji to show where she was staying.

The snapshot garnered attention from some of her famous friends, including supermodel Elle Macpherson, who wrote: 'Wow.'

Sofia Richie had a similar reaction when she commented: 'Yes.'

Talita, whose parents are Prince Alexander von Furstenberg and Alexandra Miller, later shared a picture of herself wearing a high-waisted plaid bikini while driving a boat.

'Your Uber has arrived,' she captioned the playful snapshot. 

She is likely enjoying her summer off after finishing her freshman year at Georgetown University in May.

Although she is still in school, her grandmother Diane recently told the Washington Post that Talita will definitely to go work for her fashion company.

The college student is already a brand ambassador and muse to DVF's new chief design officer Nathan Jenden.

Just last month, Talita wowed in a pale blue ruffled dress adorned with studded with 48,000 Swarovski crystals that the designer created for her to wear to the Met Gala.

Earlier this week, she and Olympia were in Austria attending a performance at the Vienna State Opera.

Olympia shared a photo of herself running into the opera house with Talita, writing: 'Off to the Opera.'

While her royal cousin will likely work in fashion, Olympia showed interest in film earlier this year when she and Sistine Stallone, 19, teamed up for a stunning photo shoot with actor Angel Elgort's lookalike older brother, Warren.

The two beauties are the subjects of the director's upcoming short film, and Warren couldn't resist sharing photos of them striking a pose while on set in April.

They are certainly no strangers to the limelight, as one is Greek royal and the other hails from Hollywood royalty.

Olympia is the daughter of Pavlos and Marie-Chantal, the Crown Prince and Princess of Greece, while Sistine is the daughter of Sly Stallone and his wife Jennifer Flavin.
item.dc:abstract: Princess Olympia of Greece, 21, took to Instagram on Monday to share a photo of herself modeling a skimpy cream slip while lying in bed (left). She also also updated her Instagram bio so that it now lists her new talent agency, Untitled Entertainment, next to her name. The management company founded by Jason Weinberg and Stephanie Simon represents a bevy of A-list clients, including Jared Leto and Naomi Watts. Olympia's princess cousin Talita, 19, posted Instagram photos of herself enjoying a seaside vacation in Greece on Monday (right and inset).
item.dc:creator: Erica Tempesta

item.title: The childhood sweethearts verses the glamour girls: How England's new World Cup wags fall into two VERY different tribes
item.description: Although the Instagram-loving glam squad came onto the scene more recently, you just can't tell the difference between them and the childhood sweethearts.
item.content:encoded:
Football is a game of two halves — and when it comes to the WAGs who will be cheering on the England football team at the World Cup from next Monday, that’s certainly true.

One side is made up of childhood sweethearts — women who met their matches while they were teenagers long before sporting stardom and riches.

And on the other you have the Instagram-loving glam squad, all bling and Bentleys, who came onto the scene more recently.

And, says ALISON BOSHOFF, can’t you just tell the difference!

Childhood sweethearts 

Winger and his jilted bride

Brunette Nicky Pike has been with Manchester United winger Ashley Young for around 15 years, since they were both pupils at the John Henry Newman School in Stevenage, Hertfordshire. Now 33, they have two children — Ellearna, nine, and Tyler, 13.

The couple were married at Stoke Place Hotel in Buckinghamshire in 2015, watched by friends including former Aston Villa player Stiliyan Petrov and former Bolton star Fabrice Muamba.

Sounds lovely — save the fact they had previously been due to marry at The Grove hotel, in Watford, Herts, in June 2011, but told guests two days beforehand that the ceremony had been called off.

Young was later seen partying with a gaggle of women in Las Vegas.

By October 2011, their relationship was back on track — and the rest is history.

DON’T MENTION: Anything about the £200,000 which was spent on the wedding that never was the first time around.

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 6/10. Second time lucky?

Graduate cuts captain down to size

Blonde fitness instructor Kate Goodland, 25, met England captain Harry Kane, 24, at primary school in East London. In 2005, the pair were pictured, aged 12, at the launch of David Beckham’s football academy in Greenwich.

Kate took a degree in Sports Science as her boyfriend made his way from Ridgeway Rovers in Chingford to Tottenham Hotspur. They got engaged last year and live in an Essex mansion. They have a daughter, Ivy, born in January 2017, and Kate is pregnant with another girl.

DON’T MENTION: When Harry said his eight hat-tricks and Golden Boot award were the greatest achievements of 2017. She tweeted: ‘First child? Engagement?’

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 10/10. As Kane said last year: ‘I’m lucky that I’ve got a childhood sweetheart.’

Defender and the girl tattooed on his arm

Raised in Barnsley, South Yorkshire, Millie Savage and John Stones, both 24, attended Penistone Grammar School and met aged 12, starting their romance when they were 15.

She followed the defender when he moved from Everton to his current club, Manchester City, where he gets paid £100,000 a week.

A low-key WAG, petite Millie is known to have a passion for her dog, Buster, and enjoys meals out at Nando’s.

Last year, Stones bought a £3.5 million house in Cheshire to share with Millie after being accused of cheating on her during a two-month affair with an events organiser. A few days after the story was published, Stones had a tattoo of Millie’s face on his arm in a bid to prove his love.

DON’T MENTION: Stones also has a tattoo (on his thigh) of ex-Barnsley favourite Norman Rimmington, known as ‘Mr Barnsley’, who was a player, coach and kitman until past the age of 90.

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 4/10. Despite that tattoo.

Centre-back and publicity-shy wife

Gemma Acton, 32, has been with Gary Cahill, 32, since they met at school in Dronfield, Derbyshire.

The couple married in 2013 and have a daughter, Freya, seven, and son, Frank, five. Centre-back Cahill has been at Chelsea since 2012 and earns £130,000 a week.

They live in a £5 million mega-mansion in Surrey, which has staff quarters as well as the footballers’ usual bar, library, gym and swimming pool.

Guests at their wedding were invited to make a donation to the Bluebell Wood Children’s Hospice in Sheffield, which offers care and support to children who have a shortened life expectancy.

DON’T MENTION: Publicity — she doesn’t have any open social media accounts and is not one of the WAGs who courts the limelight.

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 10/10 They’re clearly rock solid.

The goalie and his school sweetheart 

The romance between goalkeeper Jordan Pickford and Megan Davison started at school in Washington, Tyne and Wear. He was 16 and she was 14 — and they have been together ever since. Megan, now 22, recently graduated from university but doesn’t seem to have a job yet.

They live together in Cheshire’s blingy ‘Golden Triangle’ in a rented super-mansion. He plays for Everton and is paid £90,000 a week, making him the most expensive British goalkeeper in history.

An ‘Instagram addict’ with platinum hair and a collection of designer dresses to die for, Megan regularly posts pictures of herself on beaches around the world, generally holding a glass of champagne or pink cocktail.

DON’T MENTION: She calls Pickford her ‘bae’ (a rather cringeworthy Millennial term that means ‘Before Anyone Else’).

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 7/10. No sign of a ring, or a baby, and they’ve been together for eight years.

The glamour girls 

Midfielder and pouting queen of the selfies 

The pouting uncrowned queen of the WAGs is model Ruby Mae, a social media influencer (with 55,000 Instagram followers) who has been dating Tottenham midfielder Dele Alli for two-and-a-half years.

The couple live together in a £2 million pile in Elstree, Herts, and regularly share pictures of holidays on yachts and private jets. Ruby (a size 8 with a 32C bust) has plugged clothing brands such as Dolce & Gabbana and Rare London, and her celebrity friends include the model Lottie Moss and boxer Anthony Joshua.

Dele Alli — currently the face of clothing brand Boohoo — is negotiating a new £100,000-a-week contract with Tottenham Hotspur. He says he takes Ruby Mae out to fancy sushi restaurants Roka and Novikov in London, but adds: ‘It’s a bit different to what I was used to in Milton Keynes.’ She, in return, calls Dele ‘Boo’.

DON’T MENTION: The nightclub party in 2017 which led to cheating accusations. Hair technician Sharna Fogarty told a friend: ‘Dele called me a good girl. We all had a great time.’

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 3/10. They’re a little self-obsessed.

Right-back and his brunette beauty

Annie Kilner, 25, has been dating right-back Kyle Walker, 27, after meeting him in his hometown of Sheffield. They have two sons — Roman, six, and Riaan, two.

The model moved with Kyle from London to Cheshire after he signed for Manchester City.

She is ‘driven mad’ by Walker’s collection of 150 pairs of trainers, which he keeps pristine with baby wipes.

DON’T MENTION: The bizarre episode in 2015 when Walker had to deny that an explicit tape of a woman with a dog was anything to do with himself and Annie. ‘I am disgusted,’ he said.

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 6/10. If he can stop cleaning those trainers so much.

Striker's wife who loves botox

Head WAG is Becky Vardy, 36, whose natural beauty has been assisted by tattooed high-definition brows, hair extensions, breast implants and a spray tan. ‘I can’t bear it when women lie about this stuff. I go in the sun and I’ve hardly got any wrinkles. It’s not nature, it’s Botox,’ she said.

Becky has been married since 2016 to Leicester City and England striker Jamie Vardy, 31, whom she met when organising his birthday party in a nightclub. She will be going to Russia to support Vardy, who is negotiating a new £140,000-a-week contract. Her mother and stepfather did not attend their wedding, and nor did Jamie’s parents.

Becky has two children by Vardy, and two from previous relationships.

DON’T MENTION: Her encounter with pop star Peter Andre — she described him as a very disappointing lover.

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 9/10 Honesty is the secret to a happy marriage.

Midfielder and his oh-so-forgiving model

Model Paige Milian, 22, has been dating Manchester City’s Raheem Sterling for three years and is said to have accepted his marriage proposal last month.

Sterling, 23, who earns £200,000 a week, lives with Paige and their baby son, Thiago, in Cheshire. He has been repeatedly linked to other women including a £3,000-a-night prostitute last year. He was said to have haggled over the price of her services, then later contacted the woman saying he was too drunk to remember their night together.

DON’T MENTION: Anything about shisha pipes, nitrous oxide balloons or a gun tattoo; Raheem has run into trouble over all three. He’s also been twice accused — and cleared — of assaulting women.

HAPPY EVER AFTER RATING: 2/10. Will he settle down after the wedding?

Picture research: Claire Cisotti
item.dc:abstract: Although the Instagram-loving glam squad came onto the scene more recently, you just can't tell the difference between them and the childhood sweethearts who met their matches long before sporting stardom, says ALISON BOSHOFF. Left: Model Annie Kilner who has two sons with right-back Kyle Walker (left inset), centre top: fitness instructor Kate Goodland with England captain Harry Kane, centre bottom: Ruby Mae and midfielder Dele Alli, right: Head wag Becky Vardy who has been married to Jamie Vardy (inset) since 2016.

item.title: Too ruff for the small screen! Sex and the City creator Darren Star reveals they deleted a scene that involved one of Charlotte’s beaus receiving oral sex from his GOLDEN RETRIEVER
item.description: The scene was shot and edited for the season one episode 'The Monogamists' — and 20 years later some of the show's staffers are still shocked by it.
item.content:encoded:
Sex and the City was known for pushing boundaries and exploring sexual taboos, but one sex scene was so 'horrifying' that the footage was actually nixed by HBO. 

Speaking with Vanity Fair, the show's creator Darren Star recalled the network censoring a scene in which Charlotte (Kristin Davis) walked in and saw her beau's golden retriever 'going down on him.'

The scene was shot and edited for the season one episode 'The Monogamists' — and 20 years later some of the show's staffers are still shocked by it. 

'It was really the end of the story line,' Star said. 'He basically was always pushing her head down to give him oral sex. And he had this golden retriever who was always around. 

'In the final scene, she basically let him have it about being offended by his insistence on just wanting a blow job,' he explained. 'She accused him of only liking her for that and kind of stormed out. And then she walked back in and saw that his golden retriever was going down on him.'

Writer Amy B. Harris admitted that she is still surprised that they actually went along with filming the graphic scene.

'It’s sort of horrifying that we shot that,' she said. 'We shot him putting peanut butter on his penis, and Charlotte walks back in like, "Oh, I’m being unreasonable," and then she sees that. . . . I can’t believe we even thought about doing it.'

Charlotte's oral sex-loving boyfriend Michael Conway and his golden retriever both appear in the episode, but the story line that ended up airing is far more tame than the one that was initially written.

Michael does keep trying to steer Charlotte's head in the direction of his crotch, but they simply break up after she tells him that she isn't willing to give him oral sex because it's not something she likes to do.

The only other thing that the writers and producers could recall being censored was a shot that showed a statue of the Virgin Mary overlooking condoms that were fanned out on Miranda's nightstand.

In the season three scene featured in the episode 'Attack of the Five-Foot-Ten Woman,' Cynthia Nixon's character yells at her cleaning lady Magda for replacing the vibrator she stored in her 'goodie drawer' by her bed with a statue of the Virgin Mary.

Miranda later comes home to find that Magda left condoms on her bedside table, but show-runner Michael Patrick King explained that the initial shot they used was 'halfway censored.'

'That was an adjusted shot, because originally she had positioned the Blessed Mary to be looking over the condoms,' he explained. 'People were like, "That’s too far!" So we took Mary out.'

Aside from the few scenes that were edited, King also looked back on two story ideas that never made it to screen for two different reasons.

'It was the idea of a man who faked his own orgasm: Casper the Friendly Cum,' he said of the one premise, explaining it came from a discussion about women faking orgasms but men being unable to because 'there's physical evidence.'

They had the idea of having one of the women date a guy who seemed to be having orgasms but there wasn't any actual evidence of it. 

However, no one in the writer's room had ever experienced—or knew of anyone who had—so the idea never came to fruition.

King also had a story line idea that involved the women getting invited to a friend's house and being 'confronted by a young girl's innocent sexuality.'

He imagined the main characters being appalled to see the friend's daughter rubbing up against the edge of the couch because it felt good, but he didn't think it was 'appropriate to put a young actress in that situation.' 

'[B]ut I could have written the entire episode about it,' he admitted. 'I had been in a situation where [a relative] was just laying on a floor humping a pillow at a very young age. And everybody was kind of like, "Ahhh!"'
item.dc:abstract: Star recalled the network censoring a scene in which Charlotte (Kristin Davis) walked in and saw her beau's golden retriever (left) 'going down on him.' The scene was shot and edited for the season one episode 'The Monogamists' (left and right) — and 20 years later some of the show's staffers are still shocked by it. 'It’s sort of horrifying that we shot that,' writer Amy B. Harris admitted.

item.title: Taking the city by storm! The Fat Jew is joined by model pal Emily Ratajkowski as he parades through New York in a bright pink BATHING SUIT to celebrate National Rosé Day
item.description: Born Josh Ostrovsky, 36, The Fat Jew didn't skip a beat when it came to dressing up or rather dressing down for the occasion.
item.content:encoded:
National Rosé Day was on Saturday June 9, which brought out fans of the pink wine. One of those fans was social media star The Fat Jew who didn't skip a beat when it came to dressing up or rather dressing down for the occasion.

Born Josh Ostrovsky, 36, The Fat Jew was whose bathing suit said: 'Rosé Cleanse' on the front and paraded through the streets of New York City wearing his suit that was of course, pink in honor of the wine.

But he wasn't the only one out celebrating in honor of rosé because he was joined by model and actress Emily Ratajkowski, 27, who gave a sly smile for the camera while the Instagram star stood a few feet away. 

Back in February, The Fat Jew was a witness at Emily's city hall wedding to her now-husband Sebastian Bear-McClard, 31, who also happens to be one of his best friends.

And while it's unclear if Emily celebrated her nuptials with a glass of rosé, it's more than likely there was enough going around at the festivities on Saturday. 

In one photo, The Fat Jew can be seen sitting on top of a convertible car, sporting his bathing suit, while holding a Babe Rosé blowhorn and posing with a group of fellow rosé-lovers.

And in more photos, the comedian and Instagram influencer can be seen riding in style while he cruised in the back of his convertible through the streets of  New York City. He also he gave away free gifts to anyone wearing pink and with a good attitude.  

This was the third annual National Rosé Day parade and definitely not the first time, The Fat Jew has pulled out all the stops for the celebration.

Last year, armed with a giant rosé flag, The Fat Jew turned heads as he took off through the city in a 'Runs on Rosé' salmon-pink PT cruisersurrounded by costumed mascots Stacey and Babe, a bottle of White Girl Rosé and a can of Babe Rosé with Bubbles, who danced their way through the festivities.

He was even joined by a choir dressed in pink silk robes belting out hits by Bruno Mars, Katy Perry and Lady Gaga, as they stopped off at New York landmarks including Union Square and Washington Square Park.   

But it's more than the festive parades that make rosé and specifically Swish Beverages, the maker of White Girl Rosé and Babe Rosé, Pink Party Rosé and Family Time Is Hard Pinot Grigio, that much more successful. 

Recently, Anheuser-Busch delved into wine territory after the company acquired a stake in Swish Beverages.

And it's no wonder why because Swish's Babe Rosé, which was introduced in the summer of 2016, is the fastest selling canned wine in the industry. 

Swish has even decided to expand its original Babe product (rosé in a can with bubbles) to Pinot Grigio with bubbles, which will be the next product debuting at Swish.  

The Fat Jew made a name for himself in the world of pink wines when he launched White Girl Rosé with Babe Walker and created Swish Beverages in 2015, quickly gathering fans including the likes of Oprah Winfrey.
item.dc:abstract: Born Josh Ostrovsky, 36, The Fat Jew didn't skip a beat when it came to dressing up or rather dressing down for the occasion. He wore a swimsuit that said: 'Rosé Cleanse' on the front and paraded through the streets of New York City for the June 9 celebration. He was accompanied by the 27-year-old model and actress who gave a sly smile for the camera while the Instagram star stood a few feet away. He made a name for himself in the world of pink wines when he launched White Girl Rosé with Babe Walker and created Swish Beverages in 2015, quickly gathering fans including the likes of Oprah Winfrey.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Lankston

item.title: Bi-party-san! Tiffany Trump shares fun photos of herself posing alongside Joe Biden's granddaughter Naomi while watching Jaden Smith perform at Montauk hotspot The Surf Lodge
item.description: Tiffany, 24, took to Instagram Stories on Saturday to share a black and white photo of herself posed with Naomi, 23, as they hung out at The Surf Lodge in Montauk, New York, on Saturday.
item.content:encoded:
The divide between the Republican and Democratic parties may be widening, but Tiffany Trump put politics aside while partying with former Vice President Joe Biden's granddaughter Naomi over the weekend.

The 24-year-old first daughter took to Instagram Stories on Saturday to share a black and white photo of herself posed with Naomi, 23, as they hung out at The Surf Lodge in Montauk, New York, on Saturday.

Although it's unclear how close the two really are, they acted like they were old friends while watching Jaden Smith's Wold Ocean's Day performance.

Scroll down for video  

In the snapshot, Naomi is holding a plastic cup while she and Tiffany lean in and smile for the camera. 

Tiffany, who just finished her first year of law school at Georgetown University, looked ready for summer concert season in a low-cut white and blue patterned dress and layered necklaces.  

Meanwhile, Naomi sported ripped jeans and a white eyelet lace top that laced up the front. Both of them wore their hair loose around their shoulders, and Naomi had a pair of sunglasses sitting on top of her head. 

A video shared by their friend Allegra Blinken shows Naomi giving Tiffany a kiss on the cheek as the group posed for the camera. 

While Naomi was hanging out in the Hamptons over the weekend, her grandfather's niece Caroline Biden appeared in court on Monday after using a stolen credit card to to buy $100,000 worth of goods at C.O. Bigelow Apothecaries.  

The New York Post reported that Caroline had her felony conviction tossed on Monday​, and she was allow​ed to re-plead to the lesser charge of petit larceny as part of the plea deal she took in 2017. ​

Tiffany and Naomi both graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 2016, and the ceremony was attended by Barack Obama's vice president and Donald Trump, who was running for president at the time.

In addition to hanging out with Naomi and Allegra, Tiffany also spent the day with designer Andrew Warren; socialite Peter Brant Jr.; art publishing heir Alex Assouline; Jon Bon Jovi's son Jesse Bongiovi; Danielle Naftali, daughter of Miki Naftali of Naftali Group; and Teddy Margules, son of Eric Margules, president and CEO of Margules Properties Inc. 

Tiffany and Andrew are as close as can be, and she proudly shared a selfie she took with her best friend, writing: 'Since 3 years old.' 

She also posted a snapshot of herself cuddled up with Danielle and her French pug and a picture of the concert. 

Earlier in the day, Andrew posted a snapshot of himself posed with Tiffany at East Hampton restaurant Il Mulino. 

'Happy belated National BFD #IlMulinoMoments,' he wrote, tagging Georgica Pond as their location.

After spending the last few weeks in May in Washington, D.C. following her finals, Tiffany spent some quality time in New York city with her mom, Marla Maples, before jetting off to the Hamptons. 

On Friday, Tiffany's 54-year-old mother, Marla, took to Instagram to share photos of herself posed with her daughter and friends at the Gramercy Park Hotel.

The mother-daughter duo was joined by Uruguayan-American musician Gabe Saporta, even planner Elvira Grau, and two men named David and Jim, respectively. 

In the first snapshot, they are all posed and smiling for the camera, but the second is a blurry snapshot that shows them laughing together. 

'Sharing friendship, family & amazing uplifting conversations... welcome back to #NYC Tiff, #DavidGhiyam and Gabe,' Marla captioned the images. 'David your class on Spiritual Proactive Confrontation was off the charts. 

'Such a gift you have to help us all dig deeper and find greater peace in all situations life can bring us,' she added. 'Jim and Elvira your love and generosity always inspires! Miss you @erinfetherston.'

Marla also shared an Instagram Stories video of them walking into the restaurant. 

'Ooh I love this. This is beautiful,' Marla can be heard saying in the clip, which she captioned: 'Following the light and my girl. Hey @gabrielsaporta and @ tiffanytrump.'

After their meal, Tiffany shared a black and white Instagram Stories video of the New York City streets while she was driven past Park Avenue.

Tiffany was later seen leaving her New York City apartment flanked by a plainclothes Secret Service agent as she made her way to the Hamptons on Friday.

The first daughter was dressed casually in a wrinkled gray T-shirt, black leggings, platform espadrilles, and a wide-brimmed black hat.

She had her overnight bag on one shoulder, her purse on the other, and she carried a clear container, which contained the beads and wires she uses to make jewelry.

The Friday before, Tiffany was seen boarding Marine One with her brother Donald Trump Jr. and her sister Ivanka, who was with her husband Jared, as they joined their father, President Donald Trump, for a weekend jaunt to Camp David.
item.dc:abstract: The 24-year-old first daughter took to Instagram Stories on Saturday to share a black and white photo of herself posed with Naomi (left), 23, as they hung out at The Surf Lodge in Montauk, New York, on Saturday. Although it's unclear how close the two really are, they acted like they were old friends while watching Jaden Smith's Wold Ocean's Day performance. A video shared by their friend Allegra Blinken shows Naomi giving Tiffany a kiss on the cheek as the group posed for the camera (inset). The first daughter was also joined by her other socialite friends on Saturday, including Andrew Warren (right), Peter Brant Jr., Jesse Bongiovi, and Danielle Naftali (right).
item.dc:creator: Erica Tempesta
item.mi:shortTitle: Tiffany Trump enjoys a night out with Naomi Biden in Montauk

item.title: 'These are things I really needed as a new parent!' Mother-of-two Drew Barrymore shares a genius trick for stopping a toddler's tantrum simply by using BUBBLES
item.description: The actress, 43, posted about the bubbles hack on her Instagram account. Drew has two daughters, Olive and Frankie, with her ex-husband.
item.content:encoded:
Actress Drew Barrymore has revealed one of her genius tricks that can help soothe toddlers when they want to have a tantrum.

The mother-of-two took to Instagram to compliment an article for referencing bubbles as an easy item to keep in a diaper bag to help distract children before they get upset.

In the caption, Drew, 43,  referenced the struggles of being a new mom and how hacks like bubbles can make the process of keeping a child calm much more manageable.  

'#accountsilove @seedlingsgroup This was a great tip from them. The post said... Summer toddler tip: “keep bubbles on hand. You cannot tantrum if you are breathing and you cannot blow bubbles without breathing. You can’t tantrum while smiling while smiling and you can’t catch bubbles without lots of smiles. Quick distraction to get back to calm”,' Drew shared on her Instagram account.

Drew typically uses her Instagram account to share products and advice she has learned from other businesses and accounts. 

Her post continued: 'These are things I really needed as a new parent and I still marvel at them.

'I have worked with seedlings since my kids were born and still seek their advice regularly. 

'They also make me feel not alone as a parent as well with relatable humor.' 

Seedlings Group is a team of child development specialists and educators who work with parents to help them navigate raising a child. 

Drew advocated for their advice about bringing bubbles to places as a simple tool to keep children distracted and happy. 

She has two daughters, Olive and Frankie, with ex-husband Will Kopelman who works as an art consultant.

The couple was married for four years before divorcing in August 2016. 

While Drew's children have since moved on from the toddler phase - they are now ages four and five - she still shares hacks for new moms who follow her on Instagram. 

Most recently, she recommended toys from The Creative Toy Shop, which features play items for children that do not involve any technology.
item.dc:abstract: The actress, 43, posted about the bubbles hack on her Instagram account. Drew has two daughters, Olive, five, and Frankie, four, with her ex-husband. In the caption, Drew, 43, referenced the struggles of being a new mom and how hacks like bubbles can make the process of keeping a child calm much more manageable. She then shared advice from Seedlings Group, a team that helps new parents. This advice recommended for parents to keep bubbles with them to pull out whenever they need to distract a toddler.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Lankston
item.mi:shortTitle: Drew Barrymore shares trick for preventing a tots tantrum with BUBBLES
